detail.title: Systematic Literature Review on Comparative Analysis of Stream Ciphers Vs Block Ciphers (with a Focus on IoT, Mobile and Cloud Applications)

contentType.other: This is a Systematic Literature review that was provided by our professor for Advanced Cryptography class

detail.abstract: Cryptographic solutions are now more important than ever in protecting data storage and transmission due to the quick development of connected devices and cloud services. In order to balance performance, energy efficiency, and robust security, mobile, cloud, and Internet of Things (IoT) platforms must overcome numerous obstacles. In these resource-constrained and performance-sensitive environments, cryptographic algorithms—particularly stream and block ciphers—are the foundation of data protection mechanisms [1], [2]. A thorough assessment of stream and block cipher algorithms across cloud, mobile, and Internet of Things platforms is provided by this systematic review of the literature (SLR). The study summarizes the results of 29 publications that give details on the performance of various cryptographic algorithms in diverse real-world situations. Among them are well-known ciphers like AES, ChaCha20, RC4, Blowfish, and many others.

title: How Does the Digital Economy Affect Green Product Export Trade? Evidence from 51 Countries
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Hangzhou City University

detail.title: How Does the Digital Economy Affect Green Product Export Trade? Evidence from 51 Countries
detail.abstract: With the advancement of the green economy and sustainable development goals, green trade has become an important component of the global economy. As a new driver of development, the digital economy is deeply embedded in the export process of green products, demonstrating significant potential. Based on this, this paper focuses on the relationship between the digital economy and green product exports, exploring its impact mechanisms and policy implications. Using a sample of 51 countries from 2007 to 2022, we construct a digital economy index comprising 3 primary indicators and 14 secondary indicators, with scores calculated using factor analysis. Green product export volume serves as the dependent variable, and a two-way fixed-effects model is employed for empirical analysis of the impact mechanisms. The findings reveal: first, the digital economy significantly promotes green product exports, a result supported by multiple robustness tests; second, there are heterogeneous effects across different categories of green products and national income levels, with the digital economy having a more pronounced impact on "equipment for waste treatment and control of solids, liquids, and gases" and upper-middle-income countries; third, mechanism analysis indicates that the digital economy primarily enhances exports by driving industrial green transformation and technological innovation. Accordingly, policy recommendations are proposed to strengthen infrastructure, optimize the innovation environment, and improve green policies to promote high-quality development of green exports in China.

title: An International Law Perspective on the 12-Day Israeli-Iranian War
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: An International Law Perspective on the 12-Day Israeli-Iranian War
detail.abstract: This article provides an international legal assessment of the actions taken by Israel and Iran during the twelve-day conflict of June 2025. It focuses in particular on the illegality of preventive and anticipatory self-defence under contemporary international law, arguing that such doctrines remain legally unfounded in the absence of an actual armed attack. Through the lens of precedent cases and foundational legal instruments, the article argues that Israel’s actions constituted an unlawful act of aggression, while Iran’s response met the criteria for self-defense. The article further evaluates the relevant jus ad bellum standards governing the use of force, examines the involvement of non-state actors, and analyzes the role of third-party states in the conflict, including questions of attribution, territorial sovereignty, and incidental violations of airspace.

title: Breaking Bias: Pathways to Reducing Discrimination
affiliations: University of Milan

detail.title: Breaking Bias: Pathways to Reducing Discrimination
detail.abstract: Discrimination remains a persistent challenge with significant moral and economic consequences. While extensive economics research has documented its existence, identifying effective strategies for reducing discrimination remains an evolving field. This chapter synthesizes theoretical perspectives from economics and psychology, integrating them with recent empirical findings on discrimination reduction. It reviews interventions that mitigate bias by manipulating the cost of discrimination, shaping information processing, leveraging intergroup contact, changing attitudes, and manipulating identity perceptions. The discussion covers taste-based and statistical discrimination models, implicit bias frameworks, and psychological theories of discrimination. A particular emphasis is placed on well-identified and sufficiently powered studies, including field experiments with incentivized measures. By bridging insights across disciplines, this chapter provides a comprehensive understanding of effective discrimination reduction strategies, highlights remaining gaps, and outlines directions for future research to develop scalable solutions.

title: Bank Risk-Taking and Bank Rents: Revisiting the Franchise Value Hypothesis
affiliations: Johns Hopkins University - Carey Business School

detail.title: Bank Risk-Taking and Bank Rents: Revisiting the Franchise Value Hypothesis
detail.abstract: Using a large sample of US Bank Holding Companies during 1995-2023, we find that a standard measure of franchise value predicts lower bank capitalization and higher bank risk of insolvency. The franchise value hypothesis (FVH), postulating a negative relationship between bank franchise value and bank risk-taking, is thus rejected in our sample. We then construct proxy measures of bank pricing power rents and rents due to government guarantees, and show that an increase in either type of rents is associated with higher franchise values. Furthermore, higher rents are positively and significantly associated with higher operating costs, suggesting the existence of a rent-efficiency trade-off. To rationalize our empirical findings, we calibrate two standard financial models of the banking firm and examine the theoretical implications of a banking industry model featuring imperfect competition, agency costs, and endogenous market structure. These models support FVH incentive mechanism, but equilibrium outcomes do not necessarily imply a negative relationship between franchise value and bank risk-taking.

title: Tax Transparency in Brazil: Fundamentals, Risks and Regulatory Challenges
affiliations: University of Coimbra Institute for Legal Research

detail.title: Tax Transparency in Brazil: Fundamentals, Risks and Regulatory Challenges
detail.abstract: The introduction of tax transparency principle by Constitutional Amendment nº132/2023 represents a significant advancement in Brazilian fiscal governance, aiming for greater fairness, clarity, and efficiency in the tax system. This paper reviews its constitutional foundations, projecting anticipated positive impacts on fiscal citizenship enhancement, reduction of complexity, and compliance improvement. However, it identifies crucial implementation challenges, including privacy risks, legal uncertainties, and excessive bureaucracy. Moreover, international experience is critically analyzed, underscoring the importance of detailed infra-constitutional regulation, proper balancing between public access and tax secrecy, as well as the necessity for technological investments, administrative training, and cultural change. Comprehensive regulatory guidelines are proposed to ensure effective implementation, contributing practically and academically to regulatory and institutional debates. Thus, tax transparency emerges as an indispensable milestone to improve public governance and fiscal accountability in Brazil.

title: The End of Privacy - Philosophical Reflections and Technological Realities
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The End of Privacy - Philosophical Reflections and Technological Realities
detail.abstract:
As we navigate through the complexities of the 21st century, it becomes increasingly evident that the concept of privacy is undergoing a seismic shift, one that is profoundly reshaping our social and personal landscapes. The rapid proliferation of digital technologies, coupled with the rise of surveillance capitalism and the advancements in artificial intelligence, has propelled society into an era that many scholars and thinkers refer to as the potential "end of privacy." 

This alarming trend prompts a range of urgent inquiries concerning fundamental aspects of human existence, including the notions of freedom, autonomy, and the very essence of life in a world that is increasingly dominated by intricate technological systems. 

Collectively, the insights offered by these thinkers furnish a robust framework for analyzing the erosion of privacy, viewing it not merely as a technological occurrence but rather as a manifestation of deeper, more pervasive existential and societal crises that demand our attention and reflection.

title: Innovation and Economic Growth Nexus in Ethiopia: A Casual Relationship
affiliations: Adama Science and Technology University, Adama Science and Technology University and Seoul National University - College of Engineering

detail.title: Innovation and Economic Growth Nexus in Ethiopia: A Casual Relationship
detail.abstract: AbstractThis study investigates the causal nexus between innovation and economic growth in Ethiopia from 2011 to 2021. While theoretical frameworks posit a strong link between innovation and economic performance, this relationship remains empirically underexplored in many developing nations, including Ethiopia. The primary objective of this research is to dissect the causal pathways between disaggregated innovation inputs (such as institutions, human capital, and infrastructure) and innovation outputs (knowledge, technology, and creative outputs), and their subsequent impact on real GDP per capita growth. Employing a quantitative time-series approach, the study utilizes Vector Autoregression (VAR) models and the Toda–Yamamoto procedure for Granger causality testing to ensure robust inference in the presence of non-stationary data. The findings reveal a complex, multi-faceted relationship. We find strong evidence that innovation inputs systematically Granger-cause innovation outputs, highlighting a functional internal innovation ecosystem. Crucially, the results support a partial supply-leading hypothesis, where Knowledge and Technology Outputs are identified as the sole, direct driver of economic growth. Concurrently, evidence for a demand-following hypothesis emerges, as GDP growth is found to Granger-cause improvements in Business Sophistication and Creative Outputs. No direct bidirectional causality was observed. This research contributes by providing nuanced, evidence-based insights for Ethiopian policymakers, suggesting that strategic focus must be placed on the mechanisms that translate innovation inputs into tangible technological outputs to foster sustainable economic growth.

title: Concentration and Markups in International Trade
affiliations: Inter-American Development Bank, Bocconi University - Department of Economics, University of British Columbia (UBC) - Sauder School of Business and University of Southern California

detail.title: Concentration and Markups in International Trade
detail.abstract: This paper derives a closed-form expression linking aggregate markups on imported inputs to concentration in a model of firm-to-firm trade with two-sided market power. Our theory extends standard oligopoly insights in two dimensions. First, it reveals that markups increase with exporter concentration and decrease with importer concentration, reflecting the balance of oligopoly and oligopsony forces. Second, it adapts conventional market definitions to reflect rigid trading relationships, yielding new concentration measures that capture competition in firm-to-firm trade. Analysis of Colombian transaction-level import data shows these differences are key to understanding markup dynamics in international trade.

title: Do Recession Fears Help to Predict Stock Market Volatility? International Evidence
affiliations: Hunan University - School of Finance and Statistics, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Hunan University, School of Finance and Statistics and University of Quebec at Montreal (UQAM) - School of Management (ESG)

detail.title: Do Recession Fears Help to Predict Stock Market Volatility? International Evidence
detail.abstract: We develop a direct measure of recession fears based on Google search activity on a set of relevant terms (Recession Fear Index, RFI) and examine its risk management implications in 11 industrialized countries. We indicate that RFI is a powerful predictor for stock market volatility across countries, both in- and out-of-sample. This predictability delivers sizable utility benefits to investors and survives after controlling for common economic uncertainty factors and fundamentals. By further disentangling the driving forces of RFI,  we provide evidence that its predictability is primarily driven by the globally shared component, as well as the search activity in the United States and domains more directly tied to financial activities. Moreover, our results suggest that RFI's predictability primarily stems from its forward-looking reflection of economic conditions and and its spillover effects on investor risk preferences.

title: Lightweight and Fast High-Resolution Dichotomous Image Segmentation with Depth Guidance
affiliations: Yangzhou University, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou University, Xinjiang University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Lightweight and Fast High-Resolution Dichotomous Image Segmentation with Depth Guidance
detail.abstract: Dichotomous Image Segmentation (DIS) aims to accurately delineate objects in natural scenes. The primary challenge for the task is to accurately segment clear structures in high-resolution images while maintaining faster running speed. Most existing methods rely on powerful backbone networks to achieve high performance, but this comes at the cost of slow running speeds. Depth images have been shown to provide complementary information, but directly applying them to high-resolution images significantly increases model parameters, leading to substantial memory and GPU overhead. To address this, we propose a lightweight and fast RGB-D framework for high-resolution DIS task. We first employs a shared backbone to extract high and low-resolution RGB features. An extra backbone is used to extract complementary low-resolution depth features. Within the Attention Guided Depth Calibration (AGDC) module, two attention mechanisms are embedded to mitigate the impact of low-quality depth estimations. Finally, we decompose the ground truth into body, detail, and full masks to construct a three-branch decoder. Two symmetric decoders progressively refine the body and detail feature. Furthermore, we propose two Mutual Guided Complementary Integration (MGCI) modules at deep and shallow layers to integrate the body and detail features, respectively. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed modules, achieving competitive performance while exhibiting advantages in simplicity, efficiency (30.7 FPS), and model size (24.4 MB). The code will be available at https://github.com/orange1127chen/LFDIS_Depth-Guidance.

title: The Matched-Sign Discounting Condition: A Rule for Coherent Intertemporal Modeling
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: The Matched-Sign Discounting Condition: A Rule for Coherent Intertemporal Modeling
detail.abstract: The standard interpretation of the rate of time preference, ρ, in the discounted utility (D.U.) model yields inconsistent intuitive results when applied to the negative-sign utility functions (e.g., CRRA with θ > 1) common in modern economics. This paper argues that this is not a superficial issue, but a deep interpretive tension. We resolve this by first reexamining the mathematical foundations of discounting. We demonstrate that the discounting operator possesses a unique fixed point at the utility level of zero for any non-zero discount rate. We argue that this unique mathematical property makes u = 0 a non-arbitrary, endogenous reference point for intertemporal valuation. This finding provides a new, rigorous foundation for challenging the axiom of strict affine invariance and formally defines a 'positive domain' (u > 0) and a 'negative domain' (u < 0). Building on this foundation, we propose a new coherence rule: the Matched-Sign Discounting Condition. This condition requires the sign of the total "Discount"-the change in value from future to present-to match an agent's expressed time orientation. We show that this axiom implies a powerful and clear rule for model specification: to coherently model a present-oriented agent, the chosen Effective Rate of Discounting, ρ, must have the same sign as the utility function, u(c). This result is rationalized by a framework that un-bundles the discounting parameter. We redefine it as being composed of a stable, innate Discount Severity, |ρ|, and a rationally chosen Operational Sign, sgn(ρ), which is used as an instrument to satisfy the matched-sign rule. A key implication of this framework is a novel, structural link between an agent's risk aversion and the qualitative direction of their savings behavior. Our model predicts a "regime switch" at θ = 1 and a rich spectrum of consumption path choices, allowing us to formally distinguish between two psychologically distinct types of savers: those who save reluctantly due to high returns, and those who save voluntarily due to precautionary motives. Furthermore, it provides a new transmission mechanism for institutional quality to influence macroeconomic dynamics. Our findings challenge the common practice of assuming ρ > 0 by default and provide a clear, actionable rule for the coherent specification of intertemporal models.

title: Import Tariff, Managerial Delegation, and Corporate Social Responsibility
affiliations: National University of Kaohsiung, National University of Kaohsiung, National Kaohsiung University of Science and Technology and National Kaohsiung University of Science and Technology

detail.title: Import Tariff, Managerial Delegation, and Corporate Social Responsibility
detail.abstract: This paper intends to compare the welfare impacts of consumer-oriented CSR by exporting firms under two different tariff regimes. Under Cournot competition, when the substitutability of exported goods is relatively low (high), the optimal level of CSR would be higher (lower), and thus the importing country’s social welfare would be greater (less) under a discriminatory tariff compared to a uniform tariff. Furthermore, if substitutability is low (moderate), both the importing and exporting countries favor a discriminatory (uniform) tariff. It contrasts with the literature on strategic export policy, where all the importing and exporting countries have contrasting preferences on the two tariff regimes. Under Bertrand competition, we find that a discriminatory tariff policy leads to at least the same level of CSR as a uniform tariff policy, making it weakly superior in terms of welfare for the importing country.

title: Differential Effects of Education on Youth Earnings Across Sectors of Activity in Burkina Faso
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Differential Effects of Education on Youth Earnings Across Sectors of Activity in Burkina Faso
detail.abstract: This paper investigates the differentiated effects of education on youth wages in Burkina Faso depending on their employment sector (formal or informal). Using data from the 2018 Integrated Regional Survey on Employment and the Informal Sector (ERI-ESI), the analysis employs two econometric frameworks: an interaction-based linear regression model and a causal mediation model. Results show that education significantly increases wages (+44%), but the return to education remains consistent across sectors. Conversely, formal sector employment yields a substantial wage premium (+76%), of which only 8.4% can be attributed to education. These findings highlight that wage disparities between sectors are largely structural. The study calls for stronger recognition of educational qualifications in the informal sector and for inclusive policies to improve access of educated youth to formal employment.

title: Sovereign Default, Foreign Exchange-in-Advance Constraints, and Endogenous Default Costs *

detail.title: Sovereign Default, Foreign Exchange-in-Advance Constraints, and Endogenous Default Costs *

detail.abstract: I build a sovereign default model in which importing economies must cover intermediate imports using accumulated foreign exchange (reserves). This occasionally-binding constraint: explains why imports and production fall during defaults; complements models with simultaneous holdings of debt and reserves; generates endogenous default costs that increase with output; and motivates defaults for reserve conservation. The model is less reliant on ad-hoc default costs prevalent in prior quantitative sovereign default models seeking to match the data. Simulations from the model reveal average output losses in default that are greater than 10%, and a 17% fall in imports and a large reserve-to-gdp ratio.

title: A Case for Divided Government
affiliations: Charles III University of Madrid and University of Chicago

detail.title: A Case for Divided Government
detail.abstract: U.S. voters frequently complain about gridlock caused by divided government, yet they often elect such governments. To reconcile these two facts, we propose a model in which a representative voter chooses whether to elect a unified government—where a single party controls policymaking—or a divided government—where agenda-setting and veto powers are held by different parties. The government then observes a common shock and decides which of two policy dimensions to reform, if any. On the consensual policy dimension, both parties and the voter have aligned preferences (e.g., infrastructure spending), whereas on the divisive dimension (e.g., taxation), they disagree with positive probability: party l (r) has more leftist (rightist) preferences than the voter. A distinctive feature of our model is that the government faces an agenda constraint: it can reform only one dimension per term. We show that divided government sometimes leads to inefficient gridlock. Nevertheless, the voter may elect a divided government for fear that a unified government will waste its legislative time on divisive reforms, crowding out potentially beneficial consensual reforms. In a dynamic extension, we show that the expectation that the voter will elect divided governments polarizes the parties—but less so than if the voter could elect only unified governments. Hence, our paper uncovers a novel benefit of checks and balances: the ability to elect divided governments not only minimizes the inefficiencies of delegating policymaking to polarized parties, but also reduces party polarization in the first place.

title: Normative Ambiguity, Social Norms, and the Expressive Power of Law
affiliations: Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Faculty of Law and Hebrew University of Jerusalem - Faculty of Law

detail.title: Normative Ambiguity, Social Norms, and the Expressive Power of Law
detail.abstract: Legal scholars have long debated whether law, through its expressive power, can influence prevailing social norms. Empirical studies inspired by this debate have focused on establishing the existence of an expressive power. However, this dichotomous perspective overlooks the nuances of the theoretical discourse regarding the conditions under which law, independent of any enforcement, can wield greater or lesser impact on social norms. This article employs a regression discontinuity design to examine the expressive power of the law in shaping social norms and measure its sensitivity to contextual factors. Using a preregistered incentivized experimental survey (N = 2,913), we demonstrate that: (1) law, qua law, can indeed influence perceived social norms; and (2) this influence of the law is moderated by the normative clarity of the scenario. The law has the greatest impact on perceived norms in ambiguous situations; when additional normatively relevant information is provided, the expressive power of the law diminishes.

title: The Political Economy of Shitcoins
affiliations: University of Wisconsin-Madison and Cornell University - Department of Government

detail.title: The Political Economy of Shitcoins
detail.abstract: We study the political economy of cryptocurrency in a global economy comprised of states that issue fiat currency, considering the implications of crypto from the position of users, issuers, states, and the international system. The political implications of cryptocurrency follow from its ability to perform the three function of money: unit of account, medium of exchange, and store of value. From these foundations, we draw on the established literature on the political economy of international monetary relations and international finance to derive predictions about the future of cryptocurrency in a world of sovereign states. We describe four possible futures for the international monetary system: a world without cryptocurrency, a world in which cryptocurrency exists alongside fiat currency, a world in which cryptocurrency has replaced traditional fiat currency, and a techno-futuristic world in which cryptocurrency spells the end of the Westphalian state system. We evaluate the political and economic stability of each of these four scenarios. We conclude that the most like scenario is one in which crypto survives alongside traditional fiat currency, but also highlight that the future of cryptocurrency is a battle over the future of sovereign authority itself.

title: A Macroeconomic Model of Structural Monetary Policy in China
affiliations: Tsinghua University - Tsinghua University School of Economics and Management, Central University of Finance and Economics and Tsinghua University - School of Economics & Management

detail.title: A Macroeconomic Model of Structural Monetary Policy in China
detail.abstract: China's increasing use of structural monetary policy raises questions about its optimal role. This study investigates when and how SMP should be deployed using a multi-sector DSGE model incorporating distinct financing conditions and intermediary constraints for SOEs and POEs. We find that credit tightening disproportionately raises POE credit spreads, which conventional policy struggles to correct. Credit shocks significantly amplify resource misallocation and necessitate active SMP to address these specific distortions, stabilize the economy, and mitigate associated welfare losses. Our findings indicate that the justification for SMP is strongest when credit shocks significantly interact with underlying financial asymmetries between sectors.

title: Keeping the Dead Alive: Zombie Firms and Pollution
affiliations: University of Alberta - Campus Saint-Jean, The University of Machester - Alliance Manchester Business School, University of South Carolina - Moore School of Business and The University of Manchester - Alliance Manchester Business School

detail.title: Keeping the Dead Alive: Zombie Firms and Pollution
detail.abstract: Given the global rise of zombie firms—financially distressed, nonviable companies that remain active—we examine their broader societal implications, particularly in terms of environmental impact. Using novel approaches, we identify zombie firms across 46 countries between 2002 and 2020 and find that they exhibit higher carbon intensity than non-zombie firms. This association is persistent and long-term—emerging up to four years before zombification, amplifying upon zombification, and remaining elevated for at least five years afterward. The adverse environmental impact of zombie firms is particularly pronounced in low-growth economies, countries with limited innovation capacity, and in low-tech or carbon-intensive (“brown”) industries. To mitigate endogeneity concerns, we exploit the 2014–2016 oil price collapse as an exogenous shock that triggered zombie status in vulnerable firms. Our findings point to the need for policy frameworks that balance socioeconomic stability with environmental sustainability. Addressing the adverse environmental impacts of zombie firms is essential for achieving a global economy that is both sustainable and competitive.

title: Trade Interconnectedness and Imported Crisis Contagion
affiliations: London School of Commerce

detail.title: Trade Interconnectedness and Imported Crisis Contagion

keywords: Trade Interconnectedness and Imported Crisis Contagion Economic crisis

detail.abstract: Economic crises rarely remain confined within national borders; instead, they spread across countries through intricate trade networks. This study examines how trade interconnectedness amplifies crisis spillovers, transmitting economic instability across borders. Drawing on bilateral trade data from 19 countries (2000-2022), this study develops a novel "Trade Interconnectedness" (TI) measure to quantify imported (spill-in) and exported (spill-out) crisis contagion. Empirical analysis confirms that the imported crisis contagion coefficient is predominantly negative and statistically significant, signaling its detrimental impact on economic growth. Greece exhibits the strongest effect (-0.4132), highlighting the heightened vulnerability of economies with concentrated trade dependencies. Conversely, economies with diversified trade structures demonstrate greater resilience to external crises. These findings underscore the necessity of granular trade data in evaluating contagion risks, offering policymakers a dynamic framework to enhance economic resilience through trade diversification and crisis mitigation strategies.

title: E.U. Trade Restrictions, Heterogeneity among Malaysian Oil Palm Farmers, and Limiting Deforestation
affiliations: New York University (NYU) - Department of Economics

detail.title: E.U. Trade Restrictions, Heterogeneity among Malaysian Oil Palm Farmers, and Limiting Deforestation
detail.abstract: Market-level environmental policies may be easier to implement than targeted alternatives, but can suffer from within-market leakage when competing firms are heterogeneous, potentially undermining policy effectiveness. I examine this phenomenon in Malaysian regional markets by analyzing the 2017 EU trade resolution that phases out palm oil imports to reduce upstream deforestation. These markets contain two distinct producer types-smallholders and large estates-whose land expansion decisions are linked through equilibrium prices, creating potential for within-market leakage when one type reduces production in response to policy, thereby incentivizing expansion by the other type and partially offsetting intended environmental benefits. I develop and estimate a dynamic single-agent supply-side model of oil palm land-use using aggregate market data. Results show that large estate expansion substantially offsets deforestation reductions from decreased smallholder activity, as large estates benefit from lower entry costs and access to more profitable alternative land uses. Counterfactual analysis reveals that while a targeted per-unit tax on large estates would enhance deforestation reduction, large estates have strong incentives to block such policies even with full tax revenue redistribution. In contrast, sanctioning supplier quantity coordination emerges as a superior policy alternative that simultaneously prevents further deforestation by both producer types while increasing intensive margin profits for each, making it both environmentally effective and politically feasible.

title: Data Valuation in the Shadow of Agency Conflicts
affiliations: Finance Department, Hong Kong University of Science & Technology

detail.title: Data Valuation in the Shadow of Agency Conflicts
detail.abstract: This paper quantifies agency conflicts using a novel offline deep reinforcement learning (ODRL) framework. Compared to prior structural estimation approaches, this framework better captures the complexity of dynamic agency conflicts and provides a more granular measurement at the firm-year level. It estimates optimal management actions based on the objectives of maximizing compensation versus market cap. Actual actions that deviate from market-cap-maximizing actions and align with compensation-maximizing actions indicate high agency conflicts. Firms with higher agency conflicts tend to reduce investment while increasing cash holdings, acquisitions, and net payouts. This ODRL-derived measure of agency conflicts is significantly associated with common misconduct proxies, including corporate fraud, earnings management, option backdating, and opportunistic insider trading. When applied to a noisy rational expectations model, the framework reveals that investors place less value on management earnings guidance from firms with high agency conflicts due to its lower quality, shifting reliance toward analyst forecasts.

detail.abstract: In this study, using online data on prices of retailers in Moscow, we analyzed the correspondence of price behavior to certain pricing models. The present study complements previous estimates of price rigidity in the context of identifying empirical signs of certain pricing models based on Russian data. The empirical analysis is based on data about Moscow online retailers collected on a daily basis from February 2019 to June 2020. The data cover 33 food categories, 54 non-food categories and seven service categories. The work obtained the following empirical results, which, with some degree of convention, may be inherent in the Russian economy as a whole. The work did not reveal an explicit dependence of the size of the price change on the duration of the period of price unchanged. The Golosov-Luсas model turned out to be the closest in terms of coincidence of stylized factors for Moscow online retailers in the studied time period, but no complete coincidence was found. Pricing behavior of Russian retailers refers to hybrid pricing models which include pricing elements that depend both on the state of the economy and on time. Decomposition of inflation into intensive (average size of price changes) and extensive (the share of goods whose prices have changed in a given period) components indicates a significant contribution of the intensive component to the price dynamics based on Russian data. A similar result is typical for inflation dispersion in which the contribution of the intensive component to the dispersion decomposition turns out to be the highest. The results obtained are not fully stable in relation to the period under consideration and can be adjusted as the sample expands.

title: Quantum-Resilient Banking: Strategies for a Secure Transition
affiliations: Indian School of Business (ISB), Hyderabad, Indian School of Business (ISB), Hyderabad and Indian School of Business

detail.title: Quantum-Resilient Banking: Strategies for a Secure Transition
detail.abstract:
The advancements in the field of technology and telecommunication have also evolved the cyber security threat landscape. Though Quantum computing brings a lot of opportunities, Quantum computers pose a significant risk to currently used Public Key Cryptography (PKC) algorithms (RSA, ECDSA, EdDSA, DH, ECDH), with NIST mandating their deprecation by 2030 and complete removal by 2035. This urgency is heightened by predictions that state actors might possess quantum decryption capabilities as early as 2028, creating a “harvest now, decrypt later” threat. The only way to stay ahead of these attacks is to be aware of security trends, anticipate advanced threats, and build resilient defences. This study investigates the cybersecurity preparedness of India’s Banking, Financial Services, and Insurance (BFSI) sector in response to the emerging quantum computing threat.

The research, which included an analysis of the banking ecosystem, its stakeholders, and supply chains, employed a survey of approximately 118 BFSI CISOs/CTOs to assess current cybersecurity postures, awareness of quantum threats, and readiness for migrating to Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC). The survey revealed significant vulnerabilities: a substantial portion of respondents demonstrated only moderate understanding of quantum computing and a concerning lack of preparedness for PQC implementation (average score of 2.4 out of 5). While common security measures like access controls and encryption were widely implemented, more advanced techniques and future-proofing strategies were lacking. The most frequent threats in the past year were phishing (65%), DDoS (47.5%), and social engineering (40%) attacks. A majority of respondents (57.5%) believe quantum computing will pose a significant threat within three years. Most respondents rated the potential impact of quantum decryption on stolen data as extremely high. 

This study also developed a framework for PQC migration within the BFSI sector, considering data shelf life across the ecosystem. Key advantages of this framework include minimal disruption to existing infrastructure through support for hybrid implementation, straightforward deployment across various environments, and a future-proof architecture designed to counter evolving quantum threats. This framework facilitates the adoption of quantum-safe protocols while minimising disruption. 

The study results also highlighted key recommendations for accelerating PQC adoption. Most of the CIOs/CTOs believe that government action needs to prioritise establishing clear guidelines and standards (45%), fund research and development (27.5%), and facilitate stakeholder collaboration (17.5%). Around 42.5% of the CISOs/CTO feel the need for cybersecurity awareness and education, as well as certification programs. Government-funded audits and research grants were equally favored as incentives for financial institutions to prioritise PQC (30% each). Additionally, the respondents highlighted the need for a government-defined migration timeline (45%) and guidance on algorithm selection (27.5%). Finally, for enhancing collaboration, a dedicated forum or working group was strongly recommended (42.5%). 

The findings underscore the urgent need for immediate action to mitigate the risks posed by quantum computing. Recommendations include prioritising PQC migration, implementing robust key management practices, enhancing staff training, developing crypto-agile systems, and creating comprehensive data breach response plans. The results emphasise the urgency of developing and implementing a quantum-ready business model within the BFSI sector.

title:
Price Rigidity Analysis: Evidence from the E-Commerce Market

detail.title:
Price Rigidity Analysis: Evidence from the E-Commerce Market
Анализ жесткости цен в розничной онлайн-торговле Москвы
detail.abstract: The article studies price rigidity for food, non-food products and services based on daily data of online retailers in Moscow collected for the period from February 2019 to May 2020. It was found that the average price invariance period was 19.5 days. In addition, there is significant heterogeneity in the frequency of price changes: food prices change more often than non-food ones, and the cost of services changes the least often. The observed price behavior confirms the implications of time- and state-dependent models. The dependence on time is indicated, for example, by the fact that the probability of price changes sharply increases by days 335 and 353 of their invariability. This fact reinforces the conclusions on the presence of seasonality in price changes found in a number of foreign studies. The analysis also suggests that, in March–May 2020, growth in uncertainty caused by the coronavirus pandemic led to firms beginning to change prices more often and by a smaller magnitude. As a result, the share of price increases went up from 50.2% in March–May 2019 to 62.7% in March–May 2020. The number of days in which prices for any goods and services increased rose from 65 to 84 (out of 92 days in March–May). Thus, the results of this paper confirm that pricing behavior on the e-commerce market can vary significantly depending on economic conditions.

title: CLARA and CARLSON: Combination of Ensemble and Neural Network Machine Learning Methods for GDP Forecasting

detail.title: CLARA and CARLSON: Combination of Ensemble and Neural Network Machine Learning Methods for GDP Forecasting

publicationDetails.detailsText: Russian Journal of Money and Finance, 83(3), pp. 45–69.

detail.abstract: This paper is devoted to the use of ensemble and neural network machine learning methods, in particular, CatBoost and LightGBM methods and convolutional neural networks to forecast the GDP. The study uses a vintage database to identify the impact of statistical revisions on the accuracy of models. Our results show that a combination of neural network methods retains a predictive advantage over the benchmark models-a first-order autoregression, a dynamic factor model, and a Bayesian vector autoregression-across a panel of countries, including the pandemic crisis periods, based on preliminary and revised data. According to the econometric test for confidence in the set of models, convolutional and recurrent neural networks are among the most accurate methods for GDP forecasting. Revisions of the statistical data lead to an increase in the root mean square errors of the benchmark models and the ensemble and neural network machine learning methods.

detail.abstract: This paper investigates crude-oil price oil and covid-19 pandemic shocks on unemployment and economic welfare in Nigeria, South Africa, and Kenya. Using the Structural Vector Autoregressive (SVAR) model, impulse response function, and vector decomposition to analyse daily data from January 3 rd, 2020 to September 23 rd, 2021. The economic welfare and unemployment shock are an upshot of the pandemic, lockdown, and oil price shock effect. The SVAR model estimation revealed that oil price shock mirrors a change in the price of oil due to an unanticipated change in the oil market. The results also indicate that an increase in oil prices affect economic welfare and unemployment positively before the pandemic and negatively due to the lockdown, restrictions on economic and social movement, increase in the number of death and confirm cases. The impulse function analysis also revealed a reverse effect of oil price and covid-19 shock on unemployment and economic welfare. The demand side effect revealed a mix of the effect of the pandemic and oil price shock on economic welfare and the unemployment rate. The Johansen cointegration test shows the existence of long-run nexus in the series. Indicating that an increase/decrease in oil prices and covid-19 death cases has a proportional influence on economic welfare and unemployment rate. The study recommends investment in non-oil sectors and annual stimulus budget allocation for future pandemics and unforeseen economic and health crises. To cushion and mitigate future vicissitude of oil shocks.

title: Design of a Low Carbon Co2-Alternative- Water Injection Processes Using a Machine-Learning Assisted Multi-Objectives Optimization Protocol
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology

detail.title: Design of a Low Carbon Co2-Alternative- Water Injection Processes Using a Machine-Learning Assisted Multi-Objectives Optimization Protocol
detail.abstract: To achieve the goal of carbon neutrality, most current research has focused on evaluating carbon dioxide storage following injections. While relatively little attention has been paid to the CO2 emissions associated with the injection process itself. Previous studies have indicated that CO2 emissions resulting from exergy consumption during CO2 injection can account for 10% of the total amount injected, posing substantial obstacles for low-carbon development in oilfields. A notable contribution of this study is the incorporation of CO2 emission from exergy consumption into multi-objective-optimization framework. This emission metric is considered alongside cumulative oil production, CO2 storage capacity and net present value (NPV) to achieve collaborative enhancement of both recovery efficiency and environmental performance. To improve predictive accuracy, an ensemble learning approach combining deep neural networks (DNN) and support vector machines (SVM) together. Further reveal the compromise relationships among objectives though bi-objective and multi-objective optimization, and a novel application of the linear weighting method is employed to score Pareto-optimal solutions, enabling the identification of optimal compromise scenarios. Results show that compared with the original development strategy, the best-scoring solution achieves a 37% increase in cumulative oil production and enhances CO2 Storage by 38.43 million tons. Moreover, CO2 emissions per kilogram of CO2 injected are reduced from 0.053kg to 0.029kg, achieving a 45% reduction. The net present value (NPV) also increased by 48%. The proposed optimization strategy not only improves oil recovery and storage performance but also significantly reduces energy-related emissions, offering a promising pathway toward low-carbon and efficient field development.

title: Lending in the Crowd, Receivables in Decline: P2p Lending and Trade Credit
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and La Trobe University

detail.title: Lending in the Crowd, Receivables in Decline: P2p Lending and Trade Credit
detail.abstract: This study examines how peer-to-peer (P2P) lending affects firm-level trade credit provision. Using U.S panel data from 2012 to 2020, we find that higher state-level P2P activity is associated with reduced trade credit, consistent with a substitution effect. We further document that P2P lending lowers firm-level sales volatility by improving customer liquidity, thereby reducing the need for trade credit as a demand-smoothing tool. The effect is more pronounced in consumer-facing sectors, SMEs, and financially constrained firms, highlighting the important influence of FinTech on informal finance.

title: Personal Income Tax and Borrower Risk: Evidence from Small Business Lending
affiliations: Getulio Vargas Foundation (FGV) - Brazilian School of Public and Business Administration (EBAPE) and Lee Shau Kee School of Business and Administration, Hong Kong Metropolitan University

detail.title: Personal Income Tax and Borrower Risk: Evidence from Small Business Lending
detail.abstract: We study how changes in personal income taxes influence borrower risk in small business lending. Using statutory state tax changes for identification, we compare small business loans in adjacent counties across state borders in the U.S. during 2001-2018. We find a relative raise in personal income tax results in higher borrower risk and unfavorable lending outcomes, such as lower loan amounts, shorter maturities, as well as lower aggregate loan volumes and lower local loan growth rates. The evidence suggests higher personal income taxes increase borrower risk and constrains local small business lending.

title: Beyond Independent Fund Failures: Addressing Correlated Liquidations in Hedge Fund Risk Analysis
affiliations: University of Strathclyde

detail.title: Beyond Independent Fund Failures: Addressing Correlated Liquidations in Hedge Fund Risk Analysis
detail.abstract: This paper addresses a critical gap in hedge fund risk analysis by examining the role of correlated liquidations—a latent but significant source of systemic risk in financial intermediation. Prior research often assumes independent fund failures due to the complexity of modeling high-dimensional correlation structures. This paper introduces a parsimonious factor-based framework that captures co-failure patterns among Funds of Funds, proxied by each fund’s proximity to performance-tiered hedge funds. The resulting distance ratio acts as a shared factor reflecting exposure to common failure channels while maintaining economic interpretability.Monte Carlo simulations show that ignoring such interdependencies biases hazard model estimates, while incorporating the shared factor yields consistent results. Empirical analysis reveals that alignment with underperforming funds predicts higher liquidation risk, whereas proximity to stronger performers correlates with survival and superior ex-ante returns. The framework enhances out-of-sample forecasting accuracy and offers policy-relevant insights for managing systemic risk in financial institutions.

title: Blue vs. Red Rhetoric, Green Indifference: Congressional Stock Trading Amid ESG Politicization
affiliations: Texas State University, San Marcos

detail.title: Blue vs. Red Rhetoric, Green Indifference: Congressional Stock Trading Amid ESG Politicization
detail.abstract: Legislators’ dual role as policymakers and investors, combined with their partisan views on ESG issues, makes them an ideal setting to examine if investors incorporate ESG ideology in their investment decisions. Employing congressional transactional data during 2017–2024, we find no significant response in congressional trading to ESG information, regardless of demographic and political characteristics, revealing a stark disconnect between ESG stances and financial behavior. We   find evidence that congressional trading becomes responsive to corporate ESG out of electoral concern, rather than ideological commitment to ESG or market factors. Our results are robust to various empirical specifications, alternative interpretations, and an exogenous shock. These findings substantiate concerns about the politicization of ESG and challenging its financial relevance.

title: To Fine, or not to Fine: Reconciling Effective Enforcement with Fundamental Rights in Times of an Effects-based Approach to EU Competition Law
affiliations: Humboldt University of Berlin - Faculty of Law and Humboldt University of Berlin - Faculty of Law

detail.title: To Fine, or not to Fine: Reconciling Effective Enforcement with Fundamental Rights in Times of an Effects-based Approach to EU Competition Law
detail.abstract: The European Commission should consider introducing a second type of procedure for enforcing articles 101 and 102 TFEU that excludes the option to impose a fine on the infringing undertaking. This procedure could be part of a reform of Regulation 1/2003 which is currently being revised. The presumption of innocence applies to any proceeding that may result in the imposition of fines, which includes the 'beyond any reasonable doubt' standard of proof. The demanding 'beyond any reasonable doubt' standard in conjunction with a substantive test based on an assessment of the conduct's effects in any single case leads to long decisions and lengthy proceedings binding up resources. In turn, opting out of the power to impose fines at the start of the procedure allows for a less strict standard of proof, which might shorten proceedings. This could enable the Commission to pursue more cases and prohibit harmful conduct quicker. Thus, a procedure excluding fines could prove to be a valuable tool to enforcing competition law.

title: Balancing Tails When Comparing Distributions: Comprehensive Equity Index (Cei) with Application to Bias Evaluation in Operational Face Biometrics
affiliations: Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, Universidad Autonoma de Madrid, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Balancing Tails When Comparing Distributions: Comprehensive Equity Index (Cei) with Application to Bias Evaluation in Operational Face Biometrics
detail.abstract: Demographic bias in high-performance face recognition (FR) systems often eludes detection by existing metrics, especially with respect to subtle disparities in the tails of the score distribution. We introduce the Comprehensive Equity Index (CEI), a novel metric designed to address this limitation. CEI uniquely analyzes genuine and impostor score distributions separately, enabling a configurable focus on tail probabilities while also considering overall distribution shapes. Our extensive experiments (evaluating state-of-the-art FR systems, intentionally biased models, and diverse datasets) confirm CEI's superior ability to detect nuanced biases where previous methods fall short. Furthermore, we present CEIA, an automated version of the metric that enhances objectivity and simplifies practical application. CEI provides a robust and sensitive tool for operational FR fairness assessment. The proposed methods have been developed particularly for bias evaluation in face biometrics but, in general, they are applicable for comparing statistical distributions in any problem where one is interested in analyzing the distribution tails.

title: Does Tick Size Influence High-Frequency Herding? Evidence from the Japanese Equity Market
affiliations: Waseda University, Waseda University - School of Political Science and Economics, Shenzhen University and University of Shanghai for Science and Technology

detail.title: Does Tick Size Influence High-Frequency Herding? Evidence from the Japanese Equity Market
detail.abstract: We investigated high-frequency herding in TOPIX 100 index constituent stocks and examined the effect of tick size on high-frequency herding before and after tick-size reduction. Before the reduction, we found that high-frequency herding exists, and its intensity increases with the extent to which the tick size constrains quoted spreads. High-frequency herding is more pronounced during periods of low market trading volume, market volatility, and idiosyncratic volatility, whereas the effect of the tick size on herding behavior through binding constraints on quoted spreads is stronger during periods of high market trading volume, market volatility, and idiosyncratic volatility. Moreover, herding behavior varies throughout the trading day and initially appears weaker. Following the reduction, high-frequency herding becomes less pronounced, and the effect of tick size on herding behavior diminishes. Notably, the price impact of high-frequency herding tends to reverse over time, suggesting that herding behavior is mainly non-information-driven.

title: Search for Yield: How a Change to the Deposit Insurance Limit Affects Households' Portfolio Allocation
affiliations: Halle Institute for Economic Research, Hobart and William Smith Colleges and Bank of Canada

detail.title: Search for Yield: How a Change to the Deposit Insurance Limit Affects Households' Portfolio Allocation
detail.abstract: We study how an increase to the deposit insurance limit affects households’ portfolio allocation. Using unique data on individual deposit accounts, a suitable natural experiment, along with detailed information on Canadian households’ portfolio holdings, we show that households respond by drawing down deposits and shifting towards mutual funds and stocks. These outflows amount to 2.8% of outstanding household deposits. The mechanism underlying these portfolio adjustments relies on differences in deposit betas of insured vs. uninsured deposits. More generous deposit insurance coverage, hence, may result in non-trivial adjustments to household portfolios.

title: "The Role of Factoring in Enterprise Development: Empirical Evidence from Peru, 2015–2023"
affiliations: Universidad San Ignacio de Loyola and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: "The Role of Factoring in Enterprise Development: Empirical Evidence from Peru, 2015–2023"
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of factoring—implemented through electronic negotiable invoices—on the growth and performance of firms in Peru between 2015 and 2023. Using administrative panel data and a quasi-experimental design based on the difference-in-differences (DiD) method, the analysis compares firms that adopted this financial instrument with those that did not. The findings reveal that factoring adoption significantly increased firm survival rates. In the short term, it also enhanced access to credit, although this effect gradually diminished over time. The results on sales and employment show a heterogeneous pattern: while some firms experienced initial adverse effects, those that consistently utilized factoring reported sustained improvements. These findings contribute to the understanding of alternative financing mechanisms in developing economies and their role in fostering firm resilience and long-term development. The paper provides empirical evidence to inform financial policy and support instruments for micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Peru.

title: Green Innovation and Greenhouse Gas Emissions:  the Critical Role of Executive Compensation Incentives
affiliations: University of Naples Federico II, University of Naples Federico II and University of Campania Luigi Vanvitelli

detail.title: Green Innovation and Greenhouse Gas Emissions:  the Critical Role of Executive Compensation Incentives
detail.abstract: This study investigates the relationship between Green Innovation (GI) and corporate Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions, while also examining the moderating effect of ESG-based Executive Compensation Incentives (ECI) on this association. To test the research hypotheses, this study employs fixed-effects, Instrumental Variables (IV) 2 Stage Least Square (2SLS), and Generalized Methods of Moments (GMM) regression models over a sample of active listed non-financial firms from 2014 to 2023 from 28 countries of European Union.  The results show that the implementation of GI by non-financial firms in year t-1 is negatively associated with direct and indirect GHG emissions in year t, and that ESG-linked executive incentives enhance this negative association, reinforcing the environmental effectiveness of GI.   These findings offer new empirical insights into the effectiveness of innovation-based environmental strategies and the role of incentive-based governance mechanisms in supporting emission reduction goals. The study contributes to the ongoing debate on corporate decarbonization and has practical implications for policymakers, firms, and scholars engaged in climate transition and sustainable governance in the European context.

title: The Effect of Family Ties on Investment in Financial Literacy and Individual Financial Behavior
affiliations: University of Minho, University of Minho and University of Minho

detail.title: The Effect of Family Ties on Investment in Financial Literacy and Individual Financial Behavior
detail.abstract: We present an inter-temporal consumption model that integrates the effect of family ties on individual’s investment in financial literacy and how, in turn, the investment levels in financial literacy influence financial behavior. We posit that individuals with strong family ties seek financial advice from their families instead of investing in financial literacy. Thus, individuals with strong family ties tend to substitute the costs of investing in financial literacy with increased consumption or savings. The result is a sub-optimal financial literacy level for individuals with strong family ties, whom get a lower return on savings, which requires them to optimally save more. The model drives our empirical approach to analyzing the effect of family ties on financial literacy and its joint effect on financial behavior. Using micro-economic panel data, we find strong support for the model’s predictions: a strong level of family ties shows a significant negative effect on financial literacy and, consequently, on financial behavior, measured by savings, investment in complex financial instruments, wealth, and debt accumulation.

title: Undisclosed Pollution: Environmental Information Disclosure and Transboundary Pollution
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Peking University and Sheffield Hallam University

detail.title: Undisclosed Pollution: Environmental Information Disclosure and Transboundary Pollution
detail.abstract: This paper examines the impact of China’s initial environmental information disclosure (EID) on transboundary pollution. We employ a difference-in-differences specification by using a panel dataset covering counties along 20 major rivers from 2001 to 2013. The results show that EID exacerbates transboundary pollution. Specifically, following EID implementation, the most downstream county of a province emits approximately 40% more water pollutants than otherwise identical counties. The underlying mechanism appears to be more lenient enforcement of environmental penalties in these downstream counties due to EID pressures. Our analysis also reveals that this exacerbation of transboundary pollution is driven by the relocation of water-polluting firms from one county to downstream counties, rather than by an increase in newly established firms or higher pollution emissions from incumbent firms. This paper highlights an unintended consequence of EID, specifically the distortion of pollution activity distribution across regions.

title: The Informational Power of Regulatory Bank Stress Tests: A Case for Positive, But Tempered Expectations
affiliations: LIUC - Università Cattaneo and LIUC - Università Cattaneo

detail.title: The Informational Power of Regulatory Bank Stress Tests: A Case for Positive, But Tempered Expectations
detail.abstract: An analysis of the stress tests conducted on EU banks from 2011 to 2023 yields three insights into the ongoing debate on the design and informational value of these supervisory exercises. First, aside from the information-rich 2014 EU-wide stress tests that marked a regime change, the informativeness of all subsequent exercises has been limited, but, unlike the US experience, has remained stable. Second, the COVID-19 experiment provides limited evidence on the stress test effectiveness in detecting individual bank resilience to tail risks during extreme events. Third, the Covid-19 experiment also reveals that even the occurrence of a major shock does not significantly affect ST result persistence suggesting that regulators are cautious yet responsive when updating stress test design and implementation in the aftermath of a disruption. Overall, the European experience suggests that expectations regarding the informative value of stress testing banks should remain positive but tempered.

title: Green But Different: ESG Component Effects in Mineral Sector Portfolios Using Advanced Risk Metrics and Optimization Algorithms
affiliations: Urmia University, Urmia University, Urmia University of Technology and Urmia University

detail.title: Green But Different: ESG Component Effects in Mineral Sector Portfolios Using Advanced Risk Metrics and Optimization Algorithms
detail.abstract: Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) scores have become critical metrics for assessing corporate sustainability and performance. Yet, limited academic attention has been given to the distinct effects of each ESG component on firms’ financial outcomes, particularly within specific industries. This study focuses on the extractive and mineral processing sector to evaluate the isolated impact of ESG dimensions on portfolio performance. Utilizing financial and sustainability data from Refinitiv and ASSET4 for 2017-2021, we implement a portfolio optimization model based on the Glue VaR risk metric. Two algorithms were applied: the Active-set method for Quadratic Programming (QPA) and Multi-pass Iteration Particle Swarm Optimization (MIPSO). Results indicate that QPA consistently outperforms MIPSO in producing portfolios with better risk-return trade-off. The QPA-optimized portfolio achieved a risk range of [0.034909, 0.037026] and a return range of [0.00086, 0.001519], with performance differences statistically significant (p < 0.001). Furthermore, statistical analysis shows that the Environmental (E) component exerts a stronger and more significant influence on financial outcomes compared to the Social (S) and Governance (G) components. These findings fill a critical gap in ESG literature by providing a disaggregated analysis of ESG dimensions and their financial implications. The study offers practical insights for investment strategies in ESG-sensitive industries, suggesting that investors in the extractive sector should prioritize environmental metrics to enhance risk-adjusted returns. This recommendation is specially relevant for institutions integrating ESG criteria into capital allocation and portfolio design.

title: Going with the Flow: Water Pollution Reduction Mandates and Downstream Spillovers in China
affiliations: Suffolk University - Department of Economics and University of Maryland - College of Agriculture & Natural Resources

detail.title: Going with the Flow: Water Pollution Reduction Mandates and Downstream Spillovers in China
detail.abstract: We examine theoretically and empirically the effects of decentralized policy implementation on export of water pollutants. We show theoretically that China’s governance system creates incentives for local officials to use pollution abatement subsidies to reduce emissions within the jurisdiction at the expense of downstream neighbors. We use a detailed facility-level panel dataset to show empirically that both abatement capacity and emissions are lowest near downstream county boundaries and highest upstream of county population centers. A numerical simulation indicates that centralizing implementation at higher government levels would reduce emissions substantially, with the largest reductions occurring in the most heavily polluting industries.

title: The Optimal Threshold for Drug Decriminalization: A Game-Theoretic Model
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Optimal Threshold for Drug Decriminalization: A Game-Theoretic Model
detail.abstract: Despite growing interest in drug decriminalization, existing studies on decriminalization thresholds often rely on qualitative reasoning, resulting in unclear and often conflicting policy recommendations. This paper develops a dynamic game-theoretic model, grounded in the Beckerian economics of crime, to examine strategic interactions between the state and a representative drug dealer. In this framework, the state first sets the decriminalization threshold and penalty level, while the dealer later chooses the profit-maximizing drug quantity. The subgame perfect Nash equilibrium yields several key implications: the optimal threshold should always exceed average personal consumption, whilst penalties must remain harsh. In light of the theoretical result, the current methamphetamine threshold of 0.02 grams in Thailand should be increased by at least sixtyfold to approximately 1.2 grams, an amount on par with standards in Canada, the Czech Republic, and Portugal.

title: Sale Versus Licensing of a Product Innovation by an Outside Patentholder
affiliations: Universidade de Santiago de Compostela and University of the Balearic Islands

detail.title: Sale Versus Licensing of a Product Innovation by an Outside Patentholder
detail.abstract: We compare two ways for an outside patentholder to monetize a product (or quality-enhancing) innovation in a Cournot duopolistic industry: sale, i.e. transfer of patent ownership, or licensing, which retains ownership but requires decision-making as to the number of licences to grant and the corresponding contractual terms. We find that, regardless of the size (value or quality) of the innovation, the patentholder prefers sale (to a single firm which further licenses the innovation to the competitor by means of pure ad-valorem royalty) rather than licensing. Relative to the pre-innovation context, sale increases overall welfare, although it does not always benefit consumers. However, licensing may be a socially superior strategy than sale, depending on the size of the innovation. This leaves room for the regulator to intervene in technology transfers to the productive sector.

title: Evolutionary Machine Learning Meets Self-Supervised Learning: A Comprehensive Survey
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Evolutionary Machine Learning Meets Self-Supervised Learning: A Comprehensive Survey
detail.abstract: Research combining Evolutionary Machine Learning and Self-Supervised Learning has been steadily increasing in recent years. This suggests that combining these areas helps shaping evolutionary processes and automating the design of neural networks, while reducing the need for labelled data. However, no detailed surveys exist explaining how Evolutionary Machine Learning and Self-Supervised Learning can be used together. To help with this, we provide an overview of studies that bring these areas together, propose a definition for this area of research, and introduce a taxonomy for it. Finally, we point out some of the main challenges and suggest directions for future research.

detail.abstract: This Article examines the competitive dynamics in the global law market through the lens of the statutory evolution of the Rule in Hastings-Bass across various International Financial Centers (IFCs). Following the UK Supreme Court's 2013 decision in Pitt v Holt and Futter v Futter, which significantly restricted the judiciary's ability to void trustee decisions under the Rule, seven IFCs (Jersey, Bermuda, The Bahamas, the Dubai International Financial Center, the Cayman Islands, and the British Virgin Islands) enacted statutes to preserve and clarify the Rule within their jurisdictions. These legislative actions highlight the strategic adaptations by IFCs to enhance their legal frameworks and maintain a competitive edge in providing sophisticated trust services. By codifying the Rule, these jurisdictions have addressed key criticisms of the common law version, ensuring greater certainty, flexibility, and protection for trust beneficiaries. The Article argues that this evolution exemplifies the positive role of jurisdictional competition in improving legal services and facilitating international financial transactions, thereby contributing to the global economy.

title: Composition-Adjusted Wage Growth: A Robust Measure from Microdata
affiliations: Princeton University - Department of Economics and Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago

detail.title: Composition-Adjusted Wage Growth: A Robust Measure from Microdata

publicationDetails.detailsText: FRB of Chicago Working Paper No. 2025-14
publicationDetails.journalName: Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Wage growth is a key indicator of labor market conditions, but common measures often conflate individual wage changes with shifts in workforce composition. This paper develops a composition-adjusted measure of wage growth using nonparametric decomposition and program evaluation methods. The adjusted measure tracks unadjusted growth in stable periods but diverges during disruptions: during the Covid-19 pandemic, wage growth falls from 12% to 6% after adjustment. The method accommodates rich covariates, is robust to data quality issues such as rounding, heaping and top-coding, and enables distributional and subgroup analysis using micro data, offering more accurate views of underlying wage dynamics.

title: Delphos: A Reinforcement Learning Framework for Assisting Discrete Choice Model Specification
affiliations: University of Chile, University of Leeds and Independent

detail.title: Delphos: A Reinforcement Learning Framework for Assisting Discrete Choice Model Specification
detail.abstract: We introduce Delphos, a deep reinforcement learning framework for assisting the discrete choice model specification process. Unlike traditional approaches that treat model specification as a static optimisation problem, Delphos represents a paradigm shift: it frames this specification challenge as a sequential decision-making problem, formalised as a Markov Decision Process. In this setting, an agent learns to specify well-performing model candidates by choosing a sequence of modelling actions —such as selecting variables, accommodating both generic and alternative-specific taste parameters, applying non-linear transformations, and including interactions with covariates— and interacting with a modelling environment that estimates each candidate and returns a reward signal. Specifically, Delphos uses a Deep Q-Network that receives delayed rewards based on modelling outcomes (e.g., log-likelihood) and behavioural expectations (e.g., parameter signs), and distributes rewards across the sequence of actions to learn which modelling decisions lead to well-performing candidates. We evaluate Delphos on both simulated and empirical datasets, varying the size of the modelling space and the reward function. To assess the agent’s performance in navigating the model space, we analyse the learning curve, the distribution of Q-values, occupancy metrics, and Pareto fronts. Our results show that the agent learns to adaptively explore strategies to identify well-performing models across search spaces, even without prior domain knowledge. It efficiently explores large modelling spaces, concentrates its search in high-reward regions, and suggests candidates that define Pareto frontiers balancing model fit and behavioural plausibility. These findings highlight the potential of this novel adaptive, learning-based framework to assist in the model specification process.

detail.title: Willing to Act, Failing to Impact: Psychological and Social Drivers of Voluntary Climate Action

publicationDetails.detailsText: MPI Collective Goods Discussion Paper, No. 2025/13
publicationDetails.journalName: Max Planck Institute for Research on Collective Goods Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Despite widespread concern about climate change, voluntary mitigation efforts often fail to maximize impact. In two online experiments (n = 1, 500), we elicit willingness to mitigate (WTM) by allowing subjects to delete actual CO2 allowances and examine how they allocate the WTM between their own and another's footprint. While 75% contribute a nonzero WTM, allocations are often inefficient, and many avoid freely available footprint information, suggesting limited efficiency concerns. Self-reported motives show that only half prioritize impact, while others cite fairness, personal responsibility, or intuition. Moreover, both WTM and efficiency are malleable by impact-unrelated nudges: a video emphasizing personal responsibility increases both, whereas social image based on the own footprint raises WTM but reduces efficiency. Our results suggest that voluntary climate action is shaped as much by psychological and social factors as by concern for impact.

title: Riflessioni in tema di intelligenza artificiale e attività di vigilanza  (Insights on Artificial Intelligence and Financial Supervision)
