publicationDetails.journalName: Commissione Nazionale per le Societa e la Borsa (CONSOB) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
Italian abstract: Il presente lavoro analizza le implicazioni connesse all’adozione di sistemi di intelligenza artificiale (IA) nell’ambito dell’attività di vigilanza svolta dalla CONSOB. In assenza di una ricognizione sistematica sull’impiego dell’IA da parte delle amministrazioni pubbliche, si è ritenuto opportuno, in primo luogo, approfondire il quadro normativo di riferimento, nonché esaminare i più recenti orientamenti giurisprudenziali in materia. Successivamente, l’attenzione si è concentrata sul concetto di SupTech, inteso come utilizzo di tecnologie avanzate a supporto delle funzioni di vigilanza, attraverso una prima ricognizione delle principali sperimentazioni condotte da Autorità internazionali, europee e nazionali. In tale contesto, sono state esaminate in dettaglio le iniziative sperimentali avviate dalla CONSOB. Infine, dopo aver delineato i potenziali benefici e i rischi connessi all’impiego di tali tecnologie, le soluzioni SupTech sviluppate sono state analizzate alla luce dei requisiti che emergono dal quadro normativo vigente, al fine di coglierne le principali implicazioni e prospettarne possibili linee evolutive.

English abstract: This paper explores the challenges linked to the use of artificial intelligence systems in CONSOB’s market surveillance activities. Given the lack of a systematic assessment of AI adoption within public administrations, the analysis begins with an overview of the applicable legal framework and a review of recent case law. It then introduces the concept of SupTech – defined as the use of advanced technologies to enhance supervisory functions – through an initial survey of key initiatives undertaken by international, European, and national authorities. Within this context, particular attention is given to the experimental projects launched by CONSOB. Finally, the paper examines the potential benefits and risks associated with these technologies and assesses the SupTech solutions developed by CONSOB in light of current regulatory requirements, with the aim of identifying their main implications and outlining possible paths for future development.

title: Ensuring Fairness in Global Energy Transition: The Role of the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Ensuring Fairness in Global Energy Transition: The Role of the EU Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism
detail.abstract: AbstractThe European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), as part of the Fit for 55 package, introduces a carbon pricing policy for imports from carbon-intensive sectors to mitigate carbon leakage and level the playing field in global trade. This article analyses the potential of CBAM to promote fairness and transparency in climate policy, both within and beyond the EU. We examine its integration with the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), analyses the complementarity of both systems, evaluate its Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) system, and present a multi-criteria regional comparison based on environmental, circular, and social standards. The steel sector serves as a case study to illustrate economic implications and the effectiveness of carbon pricing models. Our findings suggest that while CBAM can reduce emissions and encourage innovation, its fairness depends on careful implementation, support mechanisms for developing countries, and continuous alignment with international climate goals.Keywords: Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, EU ETS, Carbon Leakage, Environmental Fairness, Steel Sector, Monitoring and Verification, Climate Policy, Trade, Sustainability

detail.title: Seeds of Inflation: Macro Modelling of Nature-Related Risks through Agricultural Prices

publicationDetails.detailsText: Banque de France Working Paper No. 1006
publicationDetails.journalName: Banque de France Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper analyses the macroeconomic materiality of nature-related risks, both physical and transition, through the illustration of the agricultural sector. Our results show that temporary shocks to major crops due to disruptions to ecosystem services could raise food inflation by over 2 percentage points and headline inflation by 0.5 point, with most of the impact materializing over a one-to two-year horizon. Should such one-off events be repeated or intensified, they could generate more persistent inflationary pressures. Moreover, in France, disorderly and unanticipated implementation of restrictions on agriculture inputs could reduce GDP by 0.2% and raise relative prices of agriculture by up to 12% over the medium to long term. These results demonstrate that while nature degradation can increase inflation, a well-planned and coordinated transition would mitigate these effects more effectively than disorderly action or inaction. The paper also underscores key modelling gaps-such as limitations in capturing nonlinearities, feedback loops, and sectoral interdependencies-while supporting better integration of nature into macro-financial frameworks for central banks and regulators.

title: Building Smarter, Faster: Technology and Policy Solutions for Canada's Housing Crisis
affiliations: CD howe

detail.title: Building Smarter, Faster: Technology and Policy Solutions for Canada's Housing Crisis
detail.abstract:
• Canada’s housing shortage is worsening. The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC) estimates that to restore 2019 affordability levels in the market, housing starts need to be doubled. CMHC is projecting a need for 430,000–480,000 housing starts annually. But the country is falling far short. Labour shortages, weak productivity in residential construction, and slow permitting processes are making it harder to meet needs.

  • Innovative construction methods – including modular, panelized, mass timber, and 3D printing – offer potential to improve productivity and accelerate housing delivery, but adoption remains limited due to high upfront costs, fragmented regulations, and insufficient data on performance in the Canadian context.

  • The federal government’s $26 billion Build Canada Homes initiative signals a strong commitment to innovation, yet without tackling regulatory, financial, and logistical obstacles, these technologies won’t scale or deliver meaningful cost savings. To realize the productivity benefits, governments must streamline permitting, harmonize building code interpretation, reduce development charges, and support workforce training, among other steps.

title: Unity Tax and the Parallel Purse: A Post-Income Fiscal Architecture for the 21st Century
affiliations: Independent Researcher

detail.title: Unity Tax and the Parallel Purse: A Post-Income Fiscal Architecture for the 21st Century
detail.abstract: This paper introduces a post-income model of federal taxation that replaces traditional tax categories—including income, corporate, payroll, and capital gains—with a universal excise on financial realization. The system, dubbed the Unity Tax, is enforced natively within financial infrastructure and imposes minimal behavioral distortion, administrative burden, or compliance complexity. Surplus revenues flow into a constitutionally protected public trust—the National Future Fund (NFF)—separated from congressional appropriation authority. This structure establishes a dual-sovereign framework: a traditional government operating budget and a parallel national endowment. The Unity model is designed to scale with financial velocity, resist evasion, reduce inequality without explicit redistribution, and enable a resilient, responsive public sector for the 21st century.

detail.title: The Effect of Food Price Volatility on Under-5 Child Mortality in Ethiopia

detail.abstract: This study investigates the relationship between food price volatility, macroeconomic factors, governance quality, and under-five child mortality in Ethiopia from 1970 to 2020. Ethiopia has experienced recurrent food price shocks, often associated with global trends, domestic supply constraints and policy changes. However, limited empirical research has assessed the impact of these shocks on vulnerable populations, particularly, children. We employ the Fourier-based Augmented Autoregressive Distributed Lag (FA-ARDL) model on time series data to capture both short-run and long-run effects, while accounting for potential structural breaks and cyclical variations. Our findings indicate that rising food price However, the study has several limitations. The reliance on available data may affect the generalizability of the findings, as the specific context of Ethiopia may not represent other countries. Additionally, the study does not account for other potential variables that could influence under-five child mortality, such as environmental factors, cultural practices, and healthcare quality. The models used, while robust, may not capture all the complexities of the relationships between variables. The use of FA-ARDL bounds testing, while powerful, has limitations in terms of its assumptions and potential biases. Conversely, improvements in economic growth, government effectiveness, and reductions in out-of-pocket health expenditures were correlated with lower child mortality rates over time. These results underscore the importance of stabilizing food prices and strengthening institutions that ensure households' access to food and health services. We contend that integrated strategies, combining food system resilience, social protection, and investment in public health infrastructure, are crucial for reducing child mortality in low-income settings. By linking food price dynamics to child health outcomes from an econometric perspective, this study contributes to the expanding body of literature at the intersection of food security, governance, and human development. These findings provide valuable insights for policymakers in Ethiopia and similar contexts facing the dual challenges of economic volatility and health vulnerability.

title: Weather-Aware AI Systems Versus Route-Optimization AI: A Comprehensive Analysis of AI Applications in Transportation Productivity
affiliations: University of Tokyo

detail.title: Weather-Aware AI Systems Versus Route-Optimization AI: A Comprehensive Analysis of AI Applications in Transportation Productivity
detail.abstract: While recent research demonstrates that AI route-optimization systems improve taxi driver productivity by 14%, this study reveals that such findings capture only a fraction of AI's potential in transportation. We examine comprehensive weather-aware AI systems that integrate deep learning meteorological prediction with machine learning positioning optimization, comparing their performance against traditional operations and route-only AI approaches. Using simulation data from 10,000 taxi operations across varied weather conditions, we find that weather-aware AI systems increase driver revenue by 107.3%, compared to 14% improvements from route-optimization alone. Weather prediction contributes the largest individual productivity gain, with strong correlations between meteorological conditions and demand (r = 0.575). Economic analysis reveals annual earnings increases of ¥13.8 million per driver, with rapid 1 payback periods and superior return on investment. These findings suggest that current AI literature significantly underestimates AI's transformative potential by focusing narrowly on routing algorithms, while weather intelligence represents an untapped $8.9 billion market opportunity. Our results indicate that future AI implementations should adopt comprehensive approaches that address multiple operational challenges simultaneously rather than optimizing isolated functions.

detail.title: The Role of Financial Development in Determining the Velocity of Money in Circulation: The Case of Jordan
detail.abstract: This paper aimed to analyze the effect of the financial progress that happened in the Jordanian economy on the velocity of money in circulation from the period 1980 to 2019. Specifically, the ratio of demand deposits to time deposits and the share of credit facilities to the private sector from GDP were used as measures of financial development while money supply (1) to GDP and money supply (2) to GDP were used as measures of the velocity of money. To achieve these goals, the paper has used the descriptive approach and the Auto-Regressive Distribution Lag (ARDL) approach. The tests showed that the variables became stationary after taking the first difference, and the variables are co-integration. The results of the study showed that. The ARDL model and cointegration test used in the paper reveal that the estimated parameters of the explanatory variables were more significant in the long term model and short term than in the short term it was not except for dynamics for the velocity of broad money (V2). The share of credit facilities to the private sector from GDP has a significant negative effect on the velocity of narrow money (V1) and has a considerable positive effect on the velocity of money in the wide range (V2). adding to the previous point, the ratio of demand deposits to time deposits has a significant positive effect on the velocity of narrow money (V1) and has a significant negative effect on the velocity of wide money (V2). finally, the interest rate has a substantial positive influence on both the velocity of money in a narrow and a wide range. Based on the results, the paper recommended the central bank of Jordan set strategies to stabilize the money demand function in the Jordanian economy. Since the dynamic change in life, communication and accessing the information the behavior of individuals regarding assets loans and spending is changing rapidly which leading to massive challenges to central banks' policy formulation regarding the velocity of money.

title: Evaluating Public Transport Accessibility Levels and The Potential for A 20-Minute City in Ali Mendjeli, Algeria Using a Geographic Information System (GIS)

detail.title: Evaluating Public Transport Accessibility Levels and The Potential for A 20-Minute City in Ali Mendjeli, Algeria Using a Geographic Information System (GIS)
detail.abstract: This study examines the accessibility of transportation, in Ali Mendjeli, Algeria using the concept of a "20-minute city" where essential amenities reachable within a 20-minute walk or bike ride. By utilizing Geographic Information System (GIS) technology and the Public Transport Accessibility Level (PTAL) method we analyze pedestrian access to transport hubs, service frequency and travel durations while considering footpath infrastructure and peak usage times. The PTAL maps generated reveal variations between the connected city center and the accessible peripheries. Our investigation delves into how this data can inform enhancements to transport links, expansion of services in underserved regions and promotion of access to opportunities. Through assessing the convenience of reaching destinations within 20 minutes this research offers insights for fostering a convenient and inclusive urban setting in Ali Mendjeli. The outcomes highlight challenges as prospects in realizing the vision of a 20 minute city through sustainable transportation options targeted improvements and incorporating accessibility, into urban planning strategies and regulations.

title: "The BRICS-Arab States Nexus: Pathways to De-dollarization and the Promise of Digital Currencies in Bilateral Trade"
affiliations: Graduate School of Business

detail.title: "The BRICS-Arab States Nexus: Pathways to De-dollarization and the Promise of Digital Currencies in Bilateral Trade"
detail.abstract: In recent years, the global move away from the U.S. dollar—known as dedollarization—has gained momentum. This shift has been fueled by a combination of economic shocks, the fallout from the COVID-19 pandemic, and rising geopolitical tensions. As a result, many countries are now rethinking their financial strategies, choosing to diversify their national reserves and engage in trade using local currencies through bilateral agreements. This paper explores how this trend is shaping economic and trade relations between the BRICS countries and the Arab states. With several Arab nations considering joining the BRICS bloc and already maintaining strong trade ties with its members, new possibilities for cooperation are emerging—especially in the context of reducing dependence on the U.S. dollar. A key player in this transition is the BRICS New Development Bank (NDB), which was founded in 2015 to finance infrastructure and sustainable development in emerging economies. Alongside this, the growing interest in digital currencies and electronic payment systems is creating new opportunities—and some challenges—for countries looking to reshape how they trade. This article delves into the main factors driving de-dollarization, examines how BRICS–Arab trade relations are evolving, and offers a critical look at the potential role of Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) and payment platforms like BRICS PAY in supporting a more diversified and resilient global trade environment. title: The Effects of Waiting Periods on Firearm Suicides in the U.S

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None.

detail.abstract: Suicide is often an impulsive act, and in the United States, nearly one-half of suicides involve a firearm, the most lethal and readily available method. In this paper, using developments in difference-indifferences design, we study the effect of waiting-period laws on firearm suicides and provide the first causal evaluation of such laws. We find that waiting periods reduce firearm suicides for men (-1.3 per 100,000), while the reduction for the overall population (-0.5 per 100,000), adults aged 55 + (-28.5 per 100,000), and white individuals (-23.1 per 100,000) was statistically insignificant. Waiting periods did not cause an increase in non-firearm suicides. The majority of confidence intervals were in the negative range, and the lack of statistically significant estimates does not mean that waiting periods did not cause a decrease in suicides. These findings provide some evidence that even brief delays in firearm access could disrupt the pathway from suicidal ideation to death, suggesting that cooling-off periods may be a crucial policy tool for suicide prevention.

title: Predicting Food Security and Identifying Livelihood Drivers in Rural Rwanda

detail.title: Predicting Food Security and Identifying Livelihood Drivers in Rural Rwanda
detail.abstract: This paper explores the drivers of rural livelihoods and food security in Rwanda by integrating machine learning (ML) and econometric models. Using data from Comprehensive Food Security and Vulnerability Analysis (CFSVA) 2021. It focuses on 7,530 rural households to identify key drivers of household livelihood and food security, as measured by household income and the Food Consumption Score (FCS) respectively. Panel regression analysis reveals that access to extension services, education, asset ownership, and land size positively influence household income, while subsistence agriculture and household disability have negative effects. Complementing this, ML models including logistic regression (Log), random forest (RF), ridge regression (Ridge), and gradient boosting (GBM) achieve over (92-93) % accuracy in classifying households' food security status. RF emerges as the best performer, highlighting critical predictors such as household income, food secure access, per capita consumption, dietary diversity (i.e.: Vitamin A, protein, and iron food compositions), and coping strategies. The findings underscore the importance of combining interpretable statistical techniques with powerful predictive tools to inform policy. Finally, the paper points to low adoption of irrigation and climate resilience practices, calling for targeted interventions to support transitions from on-farm to off-farm livelihoods and enhance rural welfare under increasing climate pressure.

detail.title: Harmonising the Lacuna between Tax Policy and Implementation
detail.abstract: Revenue generation has been a major problem in Nigeria as the country has financed deficit budgets over the years. The reason for this is the over-reliance on oil products as its main source of revenue. Due to the ineffectiveness of petroleum products as a means of income generation, the Nigerian government capitalised on taxes which is still inefficient. According to a report released by the Judicial Effectiveness Index in 2022, Nigeria ranks 119 out of 172 countries under the heading, Income Tax Rate. This ranking shows that Nigeria has not been able to effectively capitalise on tax as a means of revenue. Hence, the crux of this study is to explore the gap between tax policy and tax implementation in Nigeria. The doctrinal approach was adopted in this research as primary sources of law like the Federal Inland Revenue Service (Establishment) Act 2007 and secondary sources like textbooks, online journals, website publications as well as newspaper publications were utilized. This study found that there is a huge gap in Nigeria's tax administration system. The manuscript in conclusion asserts that active measures should be taken to effectively bridge this gap. Therefore, an effective tax collection system must be established, government wastages should be eliminated and stricter penalties for tax evasion should be put in place.

detail.abstract: This research presents a critical examination of the World Trade Organization (WTO), assessing its role in promoting free and fair trade globally. While WTO is positioned as a champion of trade liberalization, this paper explores the economic and political dynamics that hinder or enable its effectiveness-especially for developing and least developed countries (LDCs). Using both qualitative and quantitative methods, the study reviews WTO's structures, principles, and policies, while applying economic and political theories like Neoclassical Liberalism, Comparative Advantage, and Neorealism. The paper identifies a growing power shift within WTO, with emerging economies like India and Brazil asserting stronger influence, but often not fully representing the interests of LDCs. The conclusion suggests that although WTO aims to create a level playing field, power politics, protectionism, and internal contradictions pose significant barriers. A more inclusive, transparent, and flexible approach—tailored to individual country realities—is necessary for meaningful global trade reforms.

detail.abstract: The objective of the study is to analyze the nexus between trade openness, financial openness and economic growth. This paper considers the case of BRICS+ nations (countries mentioned as in BRICS Website) such as Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Saudi Arabia, Iran, UAE, Indonesia and Egypt for the time frame 2001-21. Ethiopia was not included in the study due to the problem of data unavailability. I performed exploratory data analysis for the panel data to test the nexus. I employed panel unit root test, Fixed Effects and Random Effects model. Based on the results from FE and RE, I find that, on one hand, Trade openness and FDI inflows significantly promote GDP growth within nations. While on the other hand, Milesi Ferretti has a significant negative effect on GDP growth. The RE model seems to be apt based on the Hausman test. However, I conducted the robustness checks using FE model for comparison and validation purposes. The robustness test concludes the absence of multicollinearity and presence of heteroscedasticity and autocorrelation. Granger Causality was deployed to test the causality relationship among the variables. The findings suggest the existence of a unidirectional causality from FDI inflows to GDP growth and GDP growth to Milesi-Ferretti.

title: A Simpler Look At Complexity
affiliations: Monash University , Monash University

detail.title: A Simpler Look At Complexity
detail.abstract: Kelly et al. (2024) use Random Matrix Theory (RMT) to show that highly overparameterized models can deliver superior out-of-sample performance in noisy financial data, challenging classical parsimony. I provide a simpler, transparent alternative grounded in statistical learning fundamentals. Analyzing an idealized Random Fourier Features model-a nonlinear approximation to kernel methods-I decompose the "double descent" in prediction error into a monotonically decreasing approximation bias (the "virtue" of complexity) and a non-monotonic estimation variance (its "cost"). This bias-variance lens not only demystifies the phenomenon but offers a modular framework for finance-specific enhancements, such as theoryguided structured features or adaptive regularization in return prediction. My approach bridges machine learning and asset pricing, enabling clearer diagnostics and practical extensions beyond the opaque RMT paradigm.

title: Belgium Imperialist Plunder of the Democratic Republic of Congo

detail.title: Belgium Imperialist Plunder of the Democratic Republic of Congo

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None
declarations.funderStatement: Funded wholly by the Researcher

detail.abstract:
This chapter explores the historical and contemporary dimensions of Belgium’s imperialist exploitation of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), tracing a legacy of violence, corruption, and underdevelopment rooted in colonial conquest and sustained through modern transnational interests. Beginning with the 19th-century annexation of the Congo by King Leopold II as his personal fiefdom, the chapter details the brutal regime of resource extraction—especially rubber—that subjected Congolese people to horrific human rights abuses. Despite the transition of control from Leopold to the Belgian state in 1908, exploitation persisted under the guise of colonial governance.

Following independence in 1960, the Congo's aspirations for true political and economic sovereignty were swiftly undermined by foreign interference, notably in the assassination of Prime Minister Patrice Lumumba and the installation of the Western-backed dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko. This entrenched a pattern of elite resource capture and institutional decay. The post-Cold War era ushered in a new wave of conflict, driven not only by political instability and ethnic divisions but primarily by the pursuit of the DRC’s vast mineral wealth—particularly coltan, a critical component in modern electronics.

The chapter underscores how neighboring states and multinational corporations have manipulated the DRC's internal conflicts to gain access to its resources, fueling a self-financing war economy. These actors, often shielded from accountability, perpetuate a cycle of violence and underdevelopment while evading international scrutiny due to ineffective regulation and limited media coverage. The chapter also reveals the humanitarian toll of the conflict, including the widespread use of child soldiers, sexual violence, and displacement.

Ultimately, the chapter concludes that the ongoing crisis in the DRC is a direct consequence of colonial plunder, neo-imperialist interests, and the resource curse. Without addressing the historical injustices and holding complicit external actors accountable, sustainable peace and development in the Congo will remain elusive.

title: A Rejoinder to Kelly & Malamud (2025) on Standardization and Information-Theoretic Bounds
affiliations: Monash University , Monash University

detail.title: A Rejoinder to Kelly & Malamud (2025) on Standardization and Information-Theoretic Bounds
detail.abstract:
This note offers a technical response to the comments on my paper, “High-Dimensional Learning in Finance” Fallahgoul (2025a), by Kelly & Malamud (2025) (KM). My aim is to clarify the key points of discussion, highlighting areas where there may be a disconnect between abstract theory and its practical application. I address this across two main aspects:

First, on standardization, I illustrate how the empirical methodology alters the Random Fourier Features (RFF) in ways that affect convergence to a Gaussian kernel—a property central to their justification—and may challenge the rotational symmetry (Assumption 4) and non-random limit (Assumption 3) in their Random Matrix Theory (RMT) analysis. This is supported by (Fallahgoul 2025a, Theorem 4.1) and empirical visualizations.

Second, on information-theoretic bounds, I address interpretations of their scope and applicability, providing a side-by-side clarification. A finite-sample calibration underscores the challenges of reliable learning in low signal-to-noise financial settings, contrasting required data volumes with typical short samples.

By focusing on these implementation-theory gaps, this rejoinder seeks to contribute to a clearer understanding, potentially guiding future work toward more robust frameworks, such as the simpler bias-variance approach in Fallahgoul (2025b).

detail.abstract: This paper analyses the potential of resolution technology (ResTech) as a strategic tool for improving the planning, execution, and monitoring of central counterparty (CCP) resolution processes. Building on the existing technology ecosystem in the RegTech and SupTech fields, the paper envisages a natural extension of these technologies to critical resolution functions in a context of increasing digitalisation and financial interconnectedness. Through a review of literature and institutional experiences, we identify the most relevant enabling technologies (such as AI, NLP, DLT and digital simulators), their potential applications in the preventive and executive phases, and the associated risks. The study highlights the need to strengthen institutional capacities, develop secure environments for experimentation, and foster effective international – particularly European – cooperation through bodies such as the Financial Stability Board (FSB) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). Finally, the paper proposes action plans to progressively integrate ResTech into operational and regulatory frameworks with the aim of establishing it as a key pillar for the effective, legitimate and appropriate resolution of the challenges in the digital financial system.

title: App Store Competition
affiliations: Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile and University of Padua - Department of Economics and Management

detail.title: App Store Competition
detail.abstract: We study within-device competition between integrated (e.g., Google Play or Apple's App Store) and third-party app stores. We find that competition does not lead to lower commission fees. The reason is that ad valorem fee setting implies a negative pass through of fees to app prices (Edgeworth paradox), which induces developers to adopt price parity across stores (without being required to do so by the integrated platform). As a result, consumers have no incentives to install third-party stores, and the integrated store becomes a natural monopoly. Eliminating default advantages through choice screens is unlikely to be effective. Allowing developers to steer consumers towards alternative subscription methods lowers commission fees and increases the number of apps, but also increases app prices, which may decrease consumer surplus.

title: Riding the Rate Wave: Interest Rate and Run Risks in Euro Area Banks During the 2022-2023 Monetary Cycle

detail.title: Riding the Rate Wave: Interest Rate and Run Risks in Euro Area Banks During the 2022-2023 Monetary Cycle
detail.abstract: Add full abstract text in one paragraph.This paper examines how the ECB’s 2022–2023 interest-rate hikes affected euro-area banks’ economic net worth and vulnerability to deposit runs. Drawing on granular, confidential data for 139 banks, we estimate each bank’s economic net worth and find that unrealised losses on loans and bonds averaged around 30 per cent of equity. By September 2023, however, roughly half of these losses had been offset by gains from the deposit franchise and interest-rate swaps. We develop a theoretical framework linking banks’ economic net worth and deposit-rate setting to depositor behaviour and run incentives. Further results indicate that banks with larger unrealised lossesraised their deposit rates by less - a pattern we interpret as banks leveraging a more valuable deposit franchise to fund longer-duration assets. Although euro-area banks as a whole avoided widespread runs, several institutions nonetheless carried substantial mark-to-market losses, suggesting latent fragilities.

detail.abstract: We study the effect introducing interest-bearing central bank digital currency (CBDC) has on bank intermediation, risk-taking and welfare. We model a CBDC that competes with bank deposits as a medium of exchange. Monopolistic banks issue deposits to lend to productive investment projects. CBDC does not lead to disintermediation, but it can distort bankers' investment decisions. To retain risk-averse depositors, banks need to compete with a risk-free asset (CBDC), which leads them to adjust their risk exposure and hold a safer loan portfolio. This can lead to overinvestment in risk-free (less productive) loans which is sub-optimal from a social point of view. If depositors are highly risk averse and risk-free projects are scarce in the economy, a CBDC that bears interest may lead to an overall welfare loss. Interest rate on reserves then becomes an important policy tool to crowd-out sub-optimal investment and mitigate banking sector risk.

title: Quantum-Inspired AI Governance Models for Post-CMOS VLSI Roadmapping

detail.title: Quantum-Inspired AI Governance Models for Post-CMOS VLSI Roadmapping
detail.abstract: The future of semiconductor governance demands planning frameworks that transcend conventional, linear roadmaps. This thesis proposes a quantum-inspired policy planning system integrating AI, stakeholder game theory, and risk-aware optimization. We introduce a multi-module architecture where input scenario corpora are transformed into branching roadmaps using a Prompt Engine Core and Strategy Synthesizer. Branch creation is modeled as a Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR)-optimized Markov Decision Process (MDP), where each node in the Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) represents a policy-action-state triple filtered by regulatory admissibility and stakeholder alignment. Key contributions include: (i) a CVaR-based risk tagging algorithm accelerated via GPU; (ii) a quantum metaphor translation layer mapping entanglement to stakeholder interdependencies and collapse to decision checkpoints; (iii) integration of statutory constraints and milestone compliance windows; and (iv) a game-theoretic payoff matrix for weighing policy actions across industry, academia, and government actors. Empirical simulations demonstrate our framework’s ability to generate realistic, regulationaligned roadmap branches with enhanced visibility into risk and opportunity trade-offs. A photonics case study transitioning from A photonics case study transitioning from 65 nm CMOS validates the planner’s utility. The system offers a foundation for future AI-assisted governance co-optimization across domains, including industrial policy, R and D investment, and supply chain localization.

detail.abstract: How does environmental, social and governance regulation of banks affect capital provision to the sustainability transition? As ambitious sustainability targets face funding challenges, the financial sector is tasked with channeling more private capital into sustainable investments. However, scaling sustainable technologies often requires investment in non-ESG-compliant assets. The mobility transition to electric vehicles, for example, demands increased supply of battery raw materials like Lithium, Cobalt, Manganese, and Nickel. This paper analyzes how ESG regulation impacts capital provision to mining companies supplying these materials. Concretely, we assess effects of the European Union’s Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation and of the Taxonomy on banks’ public holdings and cost of capital, using two large, novel data sets. We find that the introduction of the ESG regulations has a dampening effect on banks’ holdings in battery raw material mining companies, in particular those with poor ESG performance. The companies’ cost of capital and lending behavior remain unchanged.

detail.abstract: Despite the documented benefits of algorithmic decision-making, individuals often prefer to retain control rather than delegate decisions to AI agents. To what extent are the aversion to and distrust of algorithms rooted in a fundamental discomfort with giving up decision authority? Using two incentivized laboratory experiments across distinct decision domains, hiring (social decision-making) and forecasting (analytical decision-making), and decision architecture (nature and number of decisions), we elicit participants' willingness to delegate decisions separately to an AI agent and a human agent. This within-subject design enables a direct comparison of delegation preferences across different agent types. We find that participants consistently underutilize both agents, even when informed of the agents' superior performance. However, participants are more willing to delegate to the AI agent than to the human agent. Our results suggest that algorithm aversion may be driven less by distrust in AI and more by a general preference for decision autonomy. This implies that efforts to increase algorithm adoption should address broader concerns about control, rather than focusing solely on trust-building interventions.

detail.abstract: In the United States, patents and other exclusivity rights are the principle incentives for biopharmaceutical discovery, research and development.  While the award of a patent from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) entitles the owner to exclude others from producing or selling products that infringe the patent, a variety of regulatory exclusivities also play an important role in incentivizing pharmaceutical innovation. Patents and exclusivity apply to biopharmaceutical innovation in distinct ways.  Under the statutes, the Food, Drug, and Cosmetics Act (FDCA) for small-molecule drugs and the Public Health Service Act (PHSA) for biologics, exclusivities encompass certain delays and prohibitions on approval of competitor drugs following approval of the drug.  Beyond that, data exclusivity provides a period of time in which only the innovator may use their clinical trial data for marketing approval, preventing generic drug manufacturers from relying on that data thus providing temporary protection for the innovator company's investment in research and development.  In addressing inherent market failures, such exclusivities may encourage targeted research on public goods or work on projects with significant societal value, such as new antibiotics or the development of orphan drugs.  This chapter explores the economic functions of regulatory exclusivities in the biopharmaceutical ecosystem.  By defining the exclusivities, exploring their uses and their importance to the industry, the case is made that regulatory exclusivities are essential in promoting a balance between new drug innovation and enhanced public access to new treatments and cures.

detail.abstract: Ethiopia's historic decision to liberalize its banking sector after five decades of protectionism represents a pivotal economic transformation with profound implications for financial stability and national development. This comprehensive review synthesizes empirical evidence from 54 developing economies and Ethiopia's unique socioeconomic context to evaluate anticipated impacts on domestic banking efficiency and economic resilience. The analysis reveals that foreign bank entry will likely catalyze substantial improvements in operational efficiency, technological innovation, and credit availability through competitive pressure and knowledge transfer. Concurrently, it may mobilize significant foreign direct investment, alleviate chronic foreign exchange shortages, and stimulate business formation in externally-financed sectors. However, these benefits are counterbalanced by substantial risks including market fragmentation favoring urban elites, small and medium enterprise (SME) financing gaps, domestic bank fragility, and heightened vulnerability to external financial shocks. Ethiopia's current macroeconomic instability-characterized by 33% inflation, liquidity constraints, and regional conflicts-amplifies these vulnerabilities. Successful implementation requires a meticulously sequenced liberalization approach incorporating robust regulatory safeguards, mandatory inclusion mechanisms, domestic bank consolidation, and macroeconomic stabilization. The window for effective policy implementation is narrow, with the coming 24 months determining whether this reform catalyzes sustainable financial development or exacerbates existing fractures in Africa's fifth-largest economy.

title: Bridging the Digital Divide: Broadband Internet Access as a Tool to Satisfy Human Purposes
affiliations: National University

detail.title: Bridging the Digital Divide: Broadband Internet Access as a Tool to Satisfy Human Purposes
detail.abstract:
Broadband internet access has become essential to participation in economic, educational, and civic life. Originally a luxury technology limited to early adopters, broadband now underpins key services such as telehealth, remote work, e-learning, and digital commerce. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated this shift by exposing the critical role broadband plays in sustaining modern society and highlighting deep gaps in access and affordability (Fine & Kanter, 2022).

Technology is fundamentally a tool used to satisfy human purposes. In the case of broadband, the purpose is clear: to connect people, enable opportunity, and support inclusion. However, broadband's actual societal impact depends not just on its technical capabilities but on how it is governed, distributed, and integrated. We can view broadband through three philosophical lenses: utopian, dystopian, and neutral. Utopians see it as a democratizing force that empowers all. Dystopians warn that it can exacerbate existing inequities or fuel surveillance. Technological neutrality, however, argues that broadband is neither inherently good nor bad; it reflects the intentions and values embedded in its governance and implementation (Danaher & Sætra, 2022).

This report adopts a neutral perspective and examines broadband as a case study in the emergence of technology as a human-centric tool. It explores the history of broadband, philosophical frameworks, and a U.S.-based global case study on broadband expansion under the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. The analysis identifies theoretical and practical gaps and evaluates governance frameworks, such as the FCC’s standards, the NIST Risk Management Framework, and the digital equity model, to assess the role of broadband in addressing or perpetuating digital inequality.

detail.abstract: The European Union (EU) aims to realize the energy transition by increasing renewable energy production and enhancing the flexibility of the energy system. Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) technology, which enables electric vehicles (EVs) to both draw power from and supply power back to the grid, presents a particularly important opportunity to contribute to this goal. However, this technology faces legal and regulatory barriers in some EU Member States, including Spain. This article investigates the contribution of V2G technology to sector coupling and examines its potential participation in balancing markets, with a specific focus on the Spanish context. Balancing markets are technically well-suited for V2G participation, but Spain's current legislation presents significant barriers. While EU level regulations supporting the integration of V2G technology were introduced under the Clean Energy for All Europeans Package, Spain's delayed or incomplete transposition of these rules into national law continues to prevent V2G from entering the Spanish electricity balancing markets. The article analyzes the key legal and regulatory factors behind this limitation, particularly the market design favoring large-scale centralized production and the absence of a legal framework for independent aggregators. Nevertheless, it concludes that recent and ongoing legislative developments in Spain offer promising signs that these obstacles may be removed in the near future. This analysis is limited to legal and regulatory aspects and does not address technical, economic, or social dimensions of V2G deployment, which are also critical to achieving full integration.

detail.abstract: Bayesian Last Layer (BLL) models focus on incorporating uncertainty in the output layer of neural networks, offering a computationally efficient alternative to more complex Bayesian models. However, the use of Gaussian priors for last layer weights in BLL models limits their ability to express complex distributions, especially when dealing with non-Gaussian, outlier-rich, or high-dimensional datasets. To address this limitation, we propose a novel approach that combines diffusion techniques with implicit priors for variational learning of Bayesian last layer weights. This method replaces traditional Gaussian weight priors with more flexible, neural network-parameterized implicit distributions, allowing for greater expressiveness in modeling complex data. Additionally, we leverage the flexibility of diffusion Stochastic Differential Equations (SDEs) to perform posterior sampling, introducing a novel objective function that captures the intricate dependencies and correlations among latent variables. This framework enables the explicit derivation of a variational lower bound for the marginal likelihood function, achieved through KL divergence minimization, which improves both posterior estimation and computational efficiency. detail.title: Blockchain-Based Secure Trusted Clusters for Multi-Tiered Social Iot Environments in Edge-Cloud Networks
detail.abstract: The rapid expansion of Social Internet of Things (SIoT) environments within edge-cloud networks necessitates robust mechanisms for secure communication and trust management. In response, this paper introduces a Blockchain-based secure Trusted Cluster (BTC) model that integrates blockchain technology with a comprehensive multi-tier trust evaluation framework. The proposed architecture delineates a three-layered approach: a data collection layer that initiates trust assessments based on data integrity and interaction metrics; an edge layer that employs router reliability and service path integrity to pre-process and securely route data; and a cloud layer that consolidates and immutably records trust scores via blockchain consensus mechanisms. By fusing direct trust—derived from time-decayed interaction and rating analyses—with indirect trust obtained through recommendations from credible nodes, the BTC model effectively mitigates a spectrum of security threats, including selective forwarding, data tampering, on-off behavior, good mouth and bad mouth attacks. Extensive simulations leveraging real-world SIoT datasets demonstrate that the BTC model significantly enhances malicious node detection rates by up to 5% while concurrently reducing the computational cost of trust evaluations by as much as 6.8%. These findings underscore the potential of blockchain-integrated trust frameworks to fortify the security, scalability, and reliability of SIoT networks in dynamic edge-cloud environments.

title: Exmop: Extensible Protocol Reverse Engineering Framework Based on Multi-Objective Optimization

detail.title: Exmop: Extensible Protocol Reverse Engineering Framework Based on Multi-Objective Optimization
detail.abstract: Protocol Reverse Engineering (PRE) has become the foundation of numerous downstream security analyses, including vulnerability mining and intrusion detection. As the mainstream PRE technique, network trace-based PRE methods utilize various protocol features (e.g., specific features or universal features) to identify fields and their semantics. However, the inherent limitations of these features consequently constrain the performance of these PRE methods, compromising their generalizability or effectiveness. To address this, we propose an Extensible Protocol Reverse Engineering Framework Based on Multi-objective OPtimization (ExMOP) that flexibly incorporates multiple basic feature rules while synergistically integrating their complementary advantages to enhance protocol field segmentation performance. Each basic feature rule can be easily formalized as an optimization objective function, transforming the protocol field segmentation problem into a constrained multi-objective optimization model. We employ the Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm to solve this model, deriving the optimal field segmentation strategy. Ultimately, we conduct comprehensive experiments on publicly available datasets of multiple Internet protocols and industrial protocols. ExMOP demonstrates superior performance across all evaluation metrics (including 81% precision, 81% recall, 86% accuracy, 80% F1-score, 11% FPR, and 60% Perfection), significantly outperforming state-ofthe-art methods, including NEMESYS (Usenix Security ’2018), AWRE (Usenix Security ’2019), NETPLIER (NDSS ’2021), and BinaryInferno (NDSS ’2023). Furthermore, experiments affirm that expanding higher-efficiency feature rules can significantly enhance ExMOP’s performance in terms of accuracy, convergence, and stability.

detail.title: Evaluating Penetration Testing Methodologies Formobile Applications: A Comparative Study of Android and Ios Security
detail.abstract: This literature review critically examines contemporary methodologies for mobile application penetration testing, with a focus on comparing the effectiveness and limitations of testing across Android and iOS platforms. Most common approaches—including Static Application Security Testing (SAST), Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST), and network-level analysis—are evaluated for their coverage and limitations in mobile-specific contexts. The review identifies a disconnect between current penetration testing tools and the proactive, secure-by-design posture promoted by standards such as OWASP MSTG and MASVS. A key theme is the divergent architecture of Android and iOS: Android’s open ecosystem supports in-depth testing through root access, emulation, and instrumentation, while iOS’s tightly controlled security model enhances baseline protection but significantly restricts third-party assessment. The study highlights the limitations of emulators, tool fragmentation, and the lack of platform-agnostic methodologies. Emerging opportunities such as DevSecOps integration, Mobile Device Management (MDM) frameworks, Apple’s Security Research Device initiative, and evolving cross-platform tools suggest future directions for more holistic and ethical testing practices. The review concludes that hybrid, cooperative, and policy-aligned testing strategies are essential to closing current methodological gaps and advancing mobile application security.    Index Terms: penetration testing, mobile application security, Android, iOS, OWASP MASVS, mobile testing tools, DevSecOps, application vulnerabilities.

title: Private Password Breach-Checking Using Obfuscated Deterministic Bloom Filter Indices

detail.title: Private Password Breach-Checking Using Obfuscated Deterministic Bloom Filter Indices
detail.abstract: This paper presents a privacy-preserving scheme for checking passwords against breach databases using obfuscated deterministic Bloom filter indices. The approach addresses critical limitations in existing methods: k-anonymity schemes leak partial hash information that can increase attack success rates by an order of magnitude, while cryptographic protocols like Oblivious PRF (OPRF) impose significant computational overhead. The proposed scheme employs deterministic noise generation to obfuscate Bloom filter queries, preventing servers from inferring passwords while maintaining the efficiency of Bloom filter lookups. Analysis demonstrates that deterministic noise provides superior privacy guarantees compared to random noise, particularly against correlation attacks over multiple queries. Experimental evaluation shows that the scheme achieves sub-millisecond query times with minimal bandwidth overhead (typically under 1KB per query) while providing strong privacy guarantees. The proposed method is particularly suitable for integration into password managers, authentication systems, and enterprise security infrastructure.

detail.abstract: Governance, Risk Management, and Compliance (GRC) comprise three essential dimensions that support organisations in implementing, executing, monitoring, and correcting information security mechanisms. Small organisations often face greater challenges in this process due to limited budgets, reduced technical staff, and the need for specialized knowledge—factors that distinguish them from larger organisations. This study aims to identify literature gaps in information security GRC for small organisations and propose a research roadmap to address these gaps. To achieve this, a Systematic Literature Mapping (SLM) was conducted, followed by a snowballing strategy to expand the coverage and capture the state of the art on GRC in this context. A total of 208 relevant studies were identified, from which 20 types of threats, 25 frameworks, 12 standards, nine tools, seven guidelines, and five recommended processes for GRC management in small organisations were extracted.

title: A Federated Gnn-Based Solution for Privacy-Aware Internet of Things (Iot) Intrusion Detection

detail.title: A Federated Gnn-Based Solution for Privacy-Aware Internet of Things (Iot) Intrusion Detection
detail.abstract: Fast-paced growth with the internet of things (IoT) has undoubtedly paved the way for significant cybersecurity threats. since the conventional intrusion detection systems which are centralized cannot effectively deal with the problems of scalability, data heterogeneity, and user privacy that arise. This paper presents a novel distributed learning system that uses graph-based neuronal network patterns to intrude detection of distributed IoT environments without data leakage. IoT networks are seen as graphs in this system, where each device represents a node and the communication links become the edges, thus allowing the neural models to grasp the complicated attack patterns as well as the structural relationships. We develop and evaluate six graph-based neural architectures, including convolutional, attention-based, and spectral methods, within the scope of a distributed learning setting so that multiple IoT sectors can work together to train detection models with no need to exchange sensitive information. Experimental results on synthetic IoT network data show that different models are optimal for detecting specific types of cyberattacks. The spectral convolution model performs best in detecting data exfiltration and unauthorized access, while the graph convolution model trained under a non-independent data distribution achieves top performance in detecting denial-of-service attacks. The attention-based model performs best for identifying malware propagation in a centralized setting. Overall, the proposed framework provides strong detection performance while enhancing privacy and reducing communication overhead. This research offers a practical, forward-looking solution for securing IoT heterogeneous systems on a broad spectrum of threats.

detail.title: A Chase-Based Approach to Consistent Answers of Analytic Queries in Star Schemas
detail.abstract: We present an approach to computing consistent answers to analytic queries in data warehouses operating under a star schema and possibly containing missing values and inconsistent data. Our approach is based on earlier work concerning consistent query answering for standard, non-analytic queries in multi-table databases. In that work we presented polynomial algorithms for computing either the exact consistent answer to a standard, non analytic query or bounds of the exact answer, depending on whether the query involves a selection condition or not. We extend this approach to computing exact consistent answers of analytic queries over star schemas, provided that the selection condition in the query involves no keys and satisfies the  property of independency  (i.e., the condition can be expressed as a conjunction of conditions each involving a single attribute). The main contributions of this paper are: (a) a polynomial algorithm for computing the exact consistent answer to a usual projection-selection-join query over a star schema under the above restrictions on the selection condition, and (b) showing that, under the same restrictions the exact consistent answer to an analytic query over a star schema can be computed in time polynomial in the size of the data warehouse.

detail.abstract: Highway pavement maintenance represents a complex knowledge-intensive engineering decision-making challenge that requires systematic integration of heterogeneous engineering knowledge, spatial data, and multi-stakeholder preferences. Traditional pavement maintenance prioritization approaches often rely on fragmented decision criteria and lack explicit knowledge representation frameworks, limiting their scientific reliability and scalability for network-level applications. Thus, this study integrated geographic information system (GIS) and multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) to develop a knowledge-driven decision support model for highway pavement maintenance prioritization. Eight decision-making factors were identified considering engineering, environment, economy, and society to ensure the reliability and effectiveness of the decision. The geographic information system was applied to process the multi-source heterogeneous information and spatial data for the eight factors, and TODIM was applied to rank the maintenance priority of pavement sections based on the preferences of decision-makers. Finally, the proposed GIS-MCDM model was applied to an existing highway network in Gansu Province, China, along with a traditional approach for comparative analysis. According to the result, compared with the traditional method, the proposed decision support tool can improve the decision-making process of policy makers and practitioners to be more rational and justifiable in managing and maintaining their highway infrastructures, to be more sustainable for the public.

detail.title: Enhancing Urban Transportation Resilience Using Graph Neural Networks with Social Event
detail.abstract: Urban Traffic Resilience Through Graph Neural Networks and Social Event Integration. Urban traffic resilience plays a vital role in daily transportation systems. Cities face increasing challenges from disruptions such as traffic congestion caused by construction, accidents, and major public events. To enable effective urban mobility planning, it is essential to forecast these disruptions and assess how quickly transportation systems can recover. A novel approach to predicting urban traffic resilience is introduced using Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) combined with integrated social event data. Urban traffic networks are modeled as dynamic graphs, which serve as simplified representations of traffic infrastructure. In these graphs, nodes represent critical locations such as intersections and roads, while edges indicate connections, including road links and traffic flow. Real-time data from sources such as mainstream media, social media platforms, and event planning systems is incorporated. This allows for consideration of disruptions caused by public events including concerts, protests, and sports gatherings, all of which have significant effects on traffic conditions. This method enhances the prediction of traffic congestion, recovery durations, and system adaptability. An advanced tool for urban traffic management is thereby provided. The model has been evaluated using real-world datasets, demonstrating its effectiveness in forecasting disruptions and offering strategies for improving traffic flow and resilience.

detail.abstract:
This report is the second study by the NYU Stern Center for Business and Human Rights on working conditions and the garment industry in Bangladesh. It is the result of a large-scale data analysis of factory data that the Center collected and analyzed from publicly available sources and a field survey conducted in June 2015. The Center’s analysis sheds light on an important, but opaque part of the garment sector: indirect suppliers.

Indirect sourcing is key to Bangladesh’s high-volume, low-cost model of garment production. Many workers are employed in factories that supply foreign brands indirectly through other, larger factories or agents. Indirect sourcing factories operate on very tight margins and with very little oversight, increasing the vulnerability of workers to safety violations and labor rights abuses.Our research reveals five key findings:

  1. There are more than 7,000 factories producing for the export market in Bangladesh, divided between direct and indirect sourcing factories. Previous estimates of the size of the sector accounted for 4,000 – 4,500 factories. The report shows that the universe of factories producing for export is much larger than previously understood, and that indirect sourcing factories are a significant driver of production and employment.

detail.abstract:
Italian abstract: Il crowdfunding è una forma di finanziamento presente ormai da diversi anni in Italia. Dal punto di vista normativo, il fenomeno è stato disciplinato nel nostro Paese già dal 2013, almeno per la parte relativa agli investimenti in equity, mentre a livello europeo una regolamentazione completa e omogenea è stata introdotta solo nel 2020 dal Regolamento (UE) 2020/1503, entrato in piena applicazione nel novembre 2023. Il presente lavoro approfondisce le opinioni e le leve che muovono i diversi attori del settore, ossia imprese, investitori e gestori di portali di crowdfunding. L’indagine ha previsto il ricorso a strumenti di analisi differenziati, sia di tipo qualitativo sia di tipo sperimentale. Le evidenze raccolte tra dicembre 2022 e gennaio 2023 nell’ambito delle indagini qualitative mostrano che gli elementi incentivanti o disincentivanti del ricorso al crowdfunding sono numerosi e afferenti a molteplici sfere, non solo di tipo funzionale e strategico ma anche di tipo attitudinale e culturale. Inoltre, la survey rivolta ai gestori di portali mostra un comparto, consapevole dei propri punti di forza e di debolezza, che si sta preparando a cogliere le opportunità derivanti dal mutato quadro normativo e a gestirne gli eventuali aspetti critici. Le evidenze dell’analisi sperimentale utilizzata per approfondire il processo decisionale degli investitori retail nell’ambito dell’equity crowdfunding mostrano, infine, come questi ultimi diano maggior peso a informazioni quali la presenza di altri investitori (professionali e retail) nella campagna o l’impegno diretto dell’imprenditore, valorizzando pertanto le informazioni disponibili

In questo quadro, tra le possibili leve attivabili per dare impulso all’ulteriore sviluppo del settore rientrano gli incentivi fiscali rivolti a investitori e imprese nonché misure volte a favorire le possibilità di smobilizzo degli strumenti oggetto di campagne di crowdfunding. Informazione e conoscenza restano i necessari presupposti della crescita del comparto, poiché in grado di incidere su elementi culturali che possono disincentivare il ricorso a tale forma di finanziamento e investimento.

English abstract: Crowdfunding is a form of financing that has been present in Italy for several years. The phenom-enon has been regulated in our country since 2013, at least insofar as equity investments are concerned. At the European level, however, a comprehensive and uniform regulatory framework was only introduced in 2020 by Regulation (EU) 2020/1503, which came into full application in November 2023. This paper examines the opinions and levers driving different actors, namely enterprises, investors and crowdfunding service providers. The study employed a range of differentiated analysis tools, including both qualitative and experimental techniques. The evidence gathered between December 2022 and January 2023 through qualitative analysis indicates that drivers and deterrents of crowdfunding are several and heterogeneous. In detail, they refer to functional and strategic aspects, as well as attitudinal and cultural considerations. In particular, the survey addressed to crowdfunding service providers revealed a sector that is aware of its strengths and weaknesses and is prepared to seize the opportunities deriving from the new regulatory framework and to manage any challenges. Finally, the results of the experimental analysis used to investi-gate the decision-making process of retail investors in equity crowdfunding show that they place greater importance on specific pieces of information, such as the participation of other investors (both profes-sional and retail) in the campaign or the direct commitment of the entrepreneur. 

In this context, crowdfunding sector could be further developed thanks to tax incentives for in-vestors and enterprises, as well as measures to facilitate the divestment of financial instruments related to crowdfunding campaigns. Information and knowledge continue to play a key role in the sector’s growth, as they have the potential to affect some of the cultural barriers that are among the most pervasive deter-rents to accessing this funding and investment channel.

title: Multi-Model Constrained Optimization for Stratified Cancer Surveillance Strategies

detail.title: Multi-Model Constrained Optimization for Stratified Cancer Surveillance Strategies

declarations.declarationOfInterest: None.

detail.abstract:
Problem definition: Early detection of cancer recurrence improves survival, but frequent surveillance is costly and increases false positives. Existing guidelines, based on expert opinion, do not optimize the trade-off between detection and cost, and overlook patient heterogeneity. We address this by designing cost-effective, clinically interpretable surveillance strategies for both the overall population and stratified subgroups. 

Methodology/results: We formulate the surveillance problem as a constrained partially observable Markov decision process (CPOMDP). To balance personalization with practical implementation, we stratify patients into clinically meaningful subpopulations and solve a multi-model CPOMDP. By applying a Bayes-adaptive aggregation method, we transform the challenge of optimizing decisions over a semi-Markov disease model with structural model uncertainty into a tractable single-model POMDP. Applying our framework to head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, we demonstrate that integrating circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) with imaging not only improves clinical performance, reducing false positives by an order of magnitude compared to current guidelines and preserving treatment timeliness, but also delivers major economic value, with potential savings of up to 300 million annually in the U.S. Importantly, the recommended surveillance policies are simple and clinically feasible, consisting of fixed ctDNA testing schedules and selective use of imaging for localization after a positive result. To support targeted implementation, we also provide optimized schedules for six clinically relevant subpopulations defined by cancer stage and smoking history. 

Managerial implications: Data-driven, decision-analytic surveillance strategies can outperform current guidelines, offering interpretable and practical policies that better align with clinical intuition and resource constraints.

title: Unleashing Innovation: Barriers, Government Support Programs, and What Works Best

detail.title: Unleashing Innovation: Barriers, Government Support Programs, and What Works Best
detail.abstract:
• With business innovation a key to improving productivity and prosperity, Canada’s underperformance in this area is a cause for concern. This Commentary explores how businesses respond to obstacles to innovation and how public policy can best support their efforts in a period of turmoil.

• This research makes two primary contributions. First, it provides novel empirical evidence on how firms actively respond to and mitigate innovation obstacles through various strategies while facing financial constraints. Second, it offers the first systematic assessment of government support programs’ effectiveness in addressing specific innovation barriers within the context of firm-level mitigation efforts.

• Firms that actively address innovation barriers – especially financial ones such as lack of capital – through government support programs or internal strategies show higher innovation rates, though financial constraints remain a persistent, partially unresolvable obstacle.

• Government support programs are most effective when combined with firms’ own efforts and show strong results for financial and market-related barriers, but less so for skill and regulatory challenges, highlighting the need for more targeted and diversified policy tools.

detail.abstract: The chief objectives of this study are to contribute to the existing knowledge and literature by conceptually reviewing some of the advanced decision-making frameworks and techniques available for supporting managers of establishment in their decision-making responsibilities and to investigate the extent of their utilization by business managers. Thus, various frameworks in decision making (such as the Analytic Hierarchy Process, DELPHI Method, Cynefin Framework, Decision Matrix Analysis, SMART, and MAUT, among others) were conceptually reviewed and found to be capable of supporting managers in resolving complex decision problems. The survey approach allowed the study to utilize primary data sources (mainly structured interviews and questionnaires) to retrieve pertinent data from managers of the ten randomly selected and notable enterprises in Nigeria. With the employment of T-Test Statistics in SPSS (ver. 25), the study found that there is limited familiarity and application of aforementioned advanced decision-making frameworks by managers of business enterprises in Nigeria-who instead were majorly familiar with the application of conventional decision approaches such as SWOT, PESTLE, et cetera. This explains the recommendation proffered by the study-for the sponsorship of business managers to on-thejob training, such as courses, workshops, conferences, seminars, webinars, symposiums, and other professional decision skills training, especially on those that would train and polish their skill on modern utilization of advanced decision making frameworks for solving decision problem in a complex environment.

detail.abstract: Frederick Douglass' surprise nomination, as the first Black D.C. Recorder of Deeds, represented yet another career milestone for the most photographed U.S. citizen of the nineteenth century. As head of the local agency responsible for registering personal property interests, Douglass played an important role in advancing local economic development, mostly by letting the world know who owns which real estate within the geographic boundaries of D.C. This point is underscored by the fact that Douglass earned the second highest salary in the U.S. federal government, which some have estimated to be as high as $40 per work day in 1886 dollars. My essay, further, builds upon this analysis by focusing on a third indicator of importance: the type, quality and quantity of local press coverage that Douglass received during his time as the D.C. Recorder (1881 to 1886).

title: Collusion and Inequitable Prices in the EU Mandatory Bid Regime
affiliations: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey - Rutgers Law School and University of Milan

detail.title: Collusion and Inequitable Prices in the EU Mandatory Bid Regime
detail.abstract: This article examines the phenomenon of collusion in corporate acquisition transactions under the framework of the EU mandatory bid rule, focusing on avoidance practices that undermine the application of the highest price paid rule. Through a comparative analysis of landmark cases in France, Italy, and Germany, this study shows how collusive arrangements—often involving side contracts — enable acquirers to offer lower prices to minority shareholders, thereby undermining shareholder protection and distorting the efficiency of the market for corporate control. This article also assesses the adequacy of legal responses at both the EU and national levels in addressing these distortions, arguing that, to effectively restore an “equitable” price, supervisory authorities should take into account any additional benefits granted to the seller of the controlling stake. Compared to valuation methods based on allegedly “objective” criteria, this approach more effectively neutralizes the distorting effects of collusion and strengthens the deterrent function of the mandatory bid rule against inefficient acquisitions.

title: The Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) after 60 Years: Key Insights, Unresolved Issues, and Future Directions
affiliations: University of Lagos - Faculty of Business Administration, University of Lagos, Institute of Management and Technology, University of Lagos and Babcock University

detail.title: The Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM) after 60 Years: Key Insights, Unresolved Issues, and Future Directions
detail.abstract: The Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM), introduced by William Sharpe in 1964, has profoundly influenced financial economics for six decades. This paper attempts a comprehensive review of the CAPM, highlighting key insights gained from extensive research, unresolved issues, and future directions. This study revisits the CAPM after six decades, evaluating its empirical validity and comparing it with multi-factor extensions across five major African stock markets: Nigeria, South Africa, Kenya, Egypt, and the BRVM. Using monthly data from 2020 to 2024, we apply Ordinary Least Squares (OLS), Fama-MacBeth two-pass regressions, and Generalized Method of Moments (GMM) to test the explanatory power of CAPM and its extensions, including the Fama-French 3- and 5-Factor models, Carhart 4-Factor model, Liquidity-Adjusted CAPM, and Consumption CAPM. Our findings support the model, showing that CAPM beta significantly explains excess returns in African markets, with statistically significant coefficients and high t-statistics across all markets. However, consistent with the argument for its extensions, multi-factor models outperform CAPM in terms of adjusted R2 and economic significance, particularly in Nigeria and South Africa. The inclusion of liquidity and consumption factors yields mixed results, offering partial support for inclusion of liquidity and consumption data in asset pricing. Model stability varies across markets, with the Fama-French 5-Factor model demonstrating the most consistent performance. These results underscore the evolving nature of asset pricing in emerging markets and highlight the need for context-specific model adaptations. The study contributes to the literature by providing robust cross-market evidence and reinforcing the relevance of multi-factor frameworks in capturing the complexities of African equity returns.

title: Beyond the Short Run: Monetary Policy and Innovation Investment
affiliations: European Central Bank (ECB), Deutsche Bundesbank and Deutsche Bundesbank - Research Center

detail.title: Beyond the Short Run: Monetary Policy and Innovation Investment
detail.abstract: This paper provides novel empirical evidence on the impact of monetary policy on innovation investment using unique firm-level data. First, we document the effect of a large, systematic monetary tightening (ECB rate increases from 0% to 4.5% during 2022-23), with average firm-level innovation cuts of 20%. These cuts persist over the medium term, indicating a sustained innovation slowdown. Second, we use the survey to identify elasticities of innovation expenditure to exogenous policy rate changes. Responses to hikes and cuts are significant and largely symmetric at the baseline rate (4.5%), though we detect potential state-dependent asymmetry due to the extensive margin. The financing channel emerges as one of the transmission channels, with more pronounced effects in firms with higher shares of bank loans and variable-rate loans. Crucially, we show that monetary policy transmits via aggregate demand, with stronger responses in firms with pessimistic demand expectations. Forward guidance provides substantial additional stimulus by reducing uncertainty about future rates, suggesting long-term, supply-side effects of announcements. These results challenge monetary long-run neutrality and are suggestive of policy endogeneity of R∗ operating through innovation-driven technology growth.
