title: Hybrid Cnn-Lstm Model for Urban Energy Load Forecasting with Iga-Xai for Smart Grids: Peak and Off-Peak Variability Insights
affiliations: University of Science and Technology Chittagong (USTC), affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Chittagong University of Engineering and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Hybrid Cnn-Lstm Model for Urban Energy Load Forecasting with Iga-Xai for Smart Grids: Peak and Off-Peak Variability Insights
detail.abstract: Urban areas face time-specific stochastic energy demand pattern, complicating the distribution of energy efficiently, keeping costs in sight. Present approaches seldom consider the intricate and multi-scaling dynamics of urban energy requirements specially during the Peak and Off-peak periods, resulting in inefficiencies and potential overloading of energy systems. To solve this, this study proposes a hybrid 1D-CNN-LSTM model to forecast short to medium-term electrical load across three critical daily interval such as Day Peak, Evening Peak and Off-Peak in urban context. Besides most existing models that focus on short-term forecasting (typically 24-72 hours), this hybrid model demonstrates robust accuracy in both peak and off-peak load predictions up to 7 days in advance. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the proposed model consistently outperforms some state-of-the-art deep learning architectures (CNN, LSTM, GRU, Transformer-LSTM), achieving the highest forecasting accuracy with an R² of 0.95+ on day-ahead predictions and maintaining reasonable performance up to 4 days in advance. The model was also capable of accurately forecasting the intricacies in the load patterns of two other major metropolitan cities, proving its generalization capability. The key contributions of this research include a comprehensive correlation analysis, the development of an improved hybrid CNN-LSTM model interpreted with Integrated Gradients Attribution (IGA) approach for eXplainable AI (XAI), extensive lag value optimization and highly accurate short and medium-term energy demand forecasting across peak and off-peak periods. The proposed method enhances urban energy management by enabling more precise load forecasting, supporting smarter grid operations, improved reliability and progress towards sustainable energy systems.

title: Multi-Factor Priority-Based Approach for Optimizing Charging Schedule of Electric Vehicles
affiliations: Ahsanullah University of Science and Technology and BRAC University

detail.title: Multi-Factor Priority-Based Approach for Optimizing Charging Schedule of Electric Vehicles
detail.abstract: The proliferating adoption of electric vehicles (EVs), coupled with uncoordinated charging behavior, presents significant challenges on power grids, especially in managing peak demand and ensuring grid stability. This article addresses these issues by proposing a multi-factor, priority-based framework to optimize EV charging schedules in centralized charging stations. The methodology employs a day-ahead scheduling algorithm based on valley-filling technique to align charging during off-peak hours. A dynamic time-of-use (TOU) tariff is derived by integrating forecasted demand with the existing static tariff structure to incentivize off-peak charging. A priority factor is assigned to each EV based on key parameters including battery capacity, anticipated travelling distance, required SOC increase and overall energy need. EVs with higher priority factors are given precedence during overloaded conditions. To resolve overloading, a genetic algorithm (GA) is used to optimally allocate EVs for discharging providing vehicle-to-grid (V2G) operations. If V2G is insufficient, a priority-based shifting mechanism reassigns lower priority vehicles to adjacent slots.  EVs that cannot be accommodated are deferred to the next scheduling cycle ensuring fair resource allocation. Simulation results incorporating 50 vehicles for charging and 10 for discharging validate the proposed approach. The dynamic TOU tariff successfully shifts charging demand to off-peak hours while priority-based reallocation meets critical charging needs.  Additionally, the average-to-peak demand ratio improves from 70.68% to 97.4% indicating enhanced load profile and resource utilization. Overall, the proposed methodology offers a technically robust and user-centric solution for EV charging optimization offering a scalable, adaptive and sustainable model for large-scale EV adoption in smart grids.

title: More than Just Fair: Legitimizing Ai Through Reciprocity, Ethical Governance and Personal Information Sharing
affiliations: Edith Cowan University, Prince Sultan University and Edith Cowan University

detail.title: More than Just Fair: Legitimizing Ai Through Reciprocity, Ethical Governance and Personal Information Sharing
detail.abstract: This research investigates how perceived reciprocity and the ethical dimensions of algorithmic governance, involving fairness, accountability, and transparency (FAT), jointly shape consumers’ willingness to share personal information, their intention to co-create value, and their perceptions of legitimacy in AI-mediated brand interactions. Grounded in social exchange theory, this research argues that ethical governance is not merely contextual but a constitutive element of reciprocity in AI-mediated interactions. Employing a two-study design, including a scenario-based experiment and a cross-sectional survey, this research reveals that while reciprocity and each FAT principle positively impact willingness to share personal information, their influence on intention to co-create value and perceived algorithmic legitimacy is largely indirect. The findings show that willingness to share personal information serves as a key mechanism linking these governance cues to downstream outcomes and exerts a direct, robust effect on perceived algorithmic legitimacy, highlighting voluntary information sharing as a legitimacy-conferring act. Moreover, high personalization of AI interactions amplifies the effect of fairness on willingness to share personal information. This research extends social exchange theory by integrating ethical governance into the structure of AI-mediated interactions and advancing a bottom-up view of legitimacy rooted in consumer agency. The research offers strategic insights for designing AI systems that align personalization with ethical safeguards to and responsible data-sharing, algorithmic legitimacy perceptions and co-creation intentions.

title: Automated Biw Datum System Generation Via Key Reference Points and Hierarchical Topology Mapping
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Zhejiang University and University of Huddersfield

detail.title: Automated Biw Datum System Generation Via Key Reference Points and Hierarchical Topology Mapping
detail.abstract: The trend of compressing new energy vehicle (NEV) development cycles to 18-24 months necessitates a breakthrough beyond traditional experience-driven methods for datum system design of the vehicle body-in-white (BIW). This paper proposes an innovative framework based on Key Reference Points (KRPs). A Hierarchical Topology Mapping Model (HTMM) is introduced to deconstruct the spatial semantic hierarchy of part functional elements, thereby eliminating ambiguity in Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing (GD&T) specifications. A KRP-centric hierarchical architecture (Component Layer - Feature Layer - Point Cloud Layer - Datum Layer) is established, integrating manufacturing process rules, structural constraints, and dimensional specifications to enable the automatic generation of quantifiable datum constraints. Furthermore, a KRP-based dimensionality reduction mapping and X-core joint reasoning mechanism is developed to support cross-platform/cross-model part datum generalization. Engineering validation demonstrates that the KRP topological correlation matrix and parametric rule transfer mechanism improves the datum design quality of body side outer panel by 4.5%, achieve 100% fulfillment of core engineering constraints in datum generalization reasoning for geometrically variant components, enhance knowledge transfer efficiency by over 85%, maintain zero defect occurrences in datum design quality. This research establishes an interpretable datum reasoning framework, providing a new paradigm for dimensional engineering and advancing BIW manufacturing towards intelligent knowledge automation.

title: Pulling Downstream: Executive Gender Pay Gap Alignment in Global Supply Chains
affiliations: Shenzhen Technology University, Central University of Finance and Economics, Central University of Finance and Economics and University of Wollongong

detail.title: Pulling Downstream: Executive Gender Pay Gap Alignment in Global Supply Chains
detail.abstract: This study examines how global supply chains influence executive gender pay disparities across 45 economies from 2006 to 2021, with a focus on the detrimental effects of downward assortative matching. We find a strong, positive relationship between customers’ and suppliers’ executive gender pay gaps (GPGs), driven not only by customers with equitable practices fostering improvements but more critically by customers with larger GPGs reinforcing or worsening disparities among suppliers. These negative spillovers suggest that poor gender equity practices among influential customers can propagate inequality across supply chains. We demonstrate that a customer’s GPG awareness shapes a supplier’s executive GPG through strategic adjustments in leadership representation to align with perceived gender equity expectations. To establish causality, we exploit the staggered implementation of gender pay transparency policies across Europe as quasi-natural experiments. Our findings confirm that customer pressure drives GPG convergence within supply chains, but also reveal that cultural and geographic proximity can constrain or intensify these effects, particularly those associated with downward influence.

title: Visualization of Construction Risks in Bim Contracts in Egypt
affiliations: Robert Gordon University, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Visualization of Construction Risks in Bim Contracts in Egypt
detail.abstract: Building Information Modelling (BIM) is transforming construction automation in developed countries, yet its full implementation in regions like Egypt remains limited due to legal, technical, and organizational risks. This study identifies and classifies BIM implementation risks into five domains: legal, design, software, management, and financial. A targeted expert questionnaire validated these risks within Egypt’s construction sector. Based on the findings, six enablers are proposed: issuing a standardized BIM protocol, establishing cyber-secure environments, formalizing the BIM Manager role, expanding insurance coverage for software-induced risks, developing collaborative platforms, and introducing fair monetary evaluation frameworks. Additionally, the study presents a decision-support software—“Risk Eliminator Add-in”—to visualize and assess BIM-related risks. The tool estimates cost and time impacts using custom equations and contour color mapping within BIM models. This research provides actionable insights to support risk-informed digital transformation in developing construction markets.

title: Testimony On Reassessing Sarbanes-Oxley: The Cost of Compliance in Today's Capital Markets Before The House of Representatives Subcommittee on Capital Markets
affiliations: Harvard Law School

detail.title: Testimony On Reassessing Sarbanes-Oxley: The Cost of Compliance in Today's Capital Markets Before The House of Representatives Subcommittee on Capital Markets
detail.abstract: This testimony offers general observations about the Sarbanes-Oxley Act (SOX), in response to proposals to dramatically change law governing audits of public companies in the US. SOX is a disclosure law, not a command and control law.  In general, disclosure laws such as SOX provide enormous benefits to the economy. Control systems long pre-dated SOX, and were not imposed by SOX. SOX never imposed a “one size fits all” rules on US businesses. The creation of the PCAOB in SOX followed from the failure of self-regulatory bodies to preserve quality audits for US public companies. The requirement that PCAOB-supervised auditors be retained by broker-dealers was a direct result of the Madoff and Stanford scandals. The PCAOB plays a particularly important role in protecting US investors in China-based companies. Evidence from research on SOX finds that it improved audit quality and public market liquidity, and that the costs it imposed fell substantially after PCAOB modified audit standards in 2007. No evidence supports SOX impeding IPOs generally.

title: Predictive Technical Analysis in Political Intelligence: Ways of Forecasting Party Support
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Predictive Technical Analysis in Political Intelligence: Ways of Forecasting Party Support
detail.abstract: This study explores the potential political applications of three technical analysis methods originally developed for stock market trading. Applying Dow Theory, Elliott Wave Theory, and Ichimoku Kinko Hyo, it investigates support for European radical parties that have experienced rapid growth since the mid-2010s. Furthermore, drawing on a recent change of government, I demonstrate that these three analytical methods can be practically applied to forecast future trends in party support. Dow Theory can be used to identify the potential long-term boundaries of party support. Elliott Wave Theory may help forecast a party's likely political trajectory over the next parliamentary term. Ichimoku Kinko Hyo can anticipate sharp increases or declines in party support 10-12 months in advance. The predictive framework presented here may be applied within institutional settings to forecast major social tensions and political crises.

detail.title: Exploring Cultural Dimensions and Employee Engagement in Indian Organizations

publicationDetails.detailsText: 4th International Conference on Multidisciplinary Research Aspects in Applied Sciences and Humanities (ICASH) 2024

detail.abstract: Employee engagement, a key driver to organisational success is greatly influenced by cultural dimensions, especially in India where their workplace blends traditional values and modern practices. This paper investigates the convergence of cultural theoretical underpinnings, e.g., Hofstede’s dimensions (power distance and collectivism) with GLOBE style characteristics on leadership. The article articulates how these frameworks sculpt the engagement model of Indian organisations, with a stronger emphasis on leadership, diversity, and workplace wellness. Scholars and practitioners have come to identify culturally adaptive approaches to leadership, specifically in terms of its ideological moorings as inspiration, collaborative, and hierarchical etiquette-based as a leading driver for employee engagement. Companies such as Infosys and the Tata Group show us how cultural diversity in HR practices (festival celebrations or learning multiple languages) leads to growth and bucket-loads of compliance. The paper also emphasises the necessity of using culturally suitable meters to measure engagement in order to fulfil what employees expect in various settings. In addition, it examines issues of implementation problems like natural human resistance to change in pyramids and the imperative of re-adjusting policies with a dynamic cultural milieu. With case study analysis and industry reports; it offers insights into design engagement practices that will work for Indian employees. This research serves the larger conversation in employee engagement by adding a cultural critique of organisations accounting for the fine print between implementing best practices from across the globe and also adapting them into cultural delivery systems to boost productivity and organisational commitment.

title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience through the Integration of Explainable AI in Demand Forecasting Methodologies and Practices
affiliations: University of Leeds

detail.title: Enhancing Supply Chain Resilience through the Integration of Explainable AI in Demand Forecasting Methodologies and Practices
detail.abstract: In an increasingly volatile global market, supply chain resilience has become paramount for organizations aiming to maintain competitiveness. This research explores the integration of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) into demand forecasting methodologies and practices as a means to enhance supply chain resilience. By providing insights into the decision-making processes of AI models, XAI facilitates greater transparency and trust among stakeholders, allowing for more informed decisions amid uncertainty. This paper reviews existing demand forecasting frameworks, analyzes the challenges posed by traditional black-box AI systems, and outlines the benefits of incorporating XAI techniques. Case studies illustrate how organizations leveraging XAI can better anticipate disruptions, adapt to shifting demand patterns, and improve collaboration across supply chain networks. Ultimately, this study underscores the critical role of XAI in fostering a more resilient and responsive supply chain landscape, offering recommendations for practitioners aiming to implement these advanced methodologies effectively.

title: The Impact of Exchange Rate Volatility on Firm Performance: Evidence from Nigerian Exchange (NGX) Group and London Stock Exchange (LSE) Group
affiliations: University of Northampton

detail.title: The Impact of Exchange Rate Volatility on Firm Performance: Evidence from Nigerian Exchange (NGX) Group and London Stock Exchange (LSE) Group
detail.abstract:
The study aims at investigating the impact of exchange rate volatility on firm performance in Nigeria and the United Kingdom economies over a period of 10 years spanning from 2014 to 2023; following the conception by the researcher to obtain understanding into the relationship that exchange rate volatility has with financial performance of businesses. The study adopted positivism paradigm and quantitative approach in investigating the impact of exchange rate volatility on firm performance The quantitative approach is ideal for the study which involves the collection and statistical analysis of numerical secondary data of selected listed companies while testing the theories to obtain research findings. The study is descriptive research that describes the impact of exchange rate volatility on firm performance using evidence from Nigerian Exchange (NGX) Group and London Stock Exchange (LSE) Group.

For companies operating in Nigeria, the result revealed that there is a weak positive relationship between exchange rate volatility and firm performance. While for businesses operating in the United Kingdom, the results revealed that there is a weak negative relationship between exchange rate volatility and firm performance. The study results contribute to the market power theory, that companies operating in less competitive markets and less regulatory environments derive unearned endowment to improve their financial performance by transferring the cost of exchange rate fluctuation to its customers. The results revealed that exchange rate fluctuation significantly impacts financial performance of companies in the United Kingdom in a negative matter possibly because of stricter market regulations as there are no price regulations in Nigeria where the impact of exchange rate volatility on firm performance is significantly weak and positive.

title: Explainable Machine Learning Models and Gpt-4 Recommendations for ESG Performance Evaluation in the Logistics Sector
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Explainable Machine Learning Models and Gpt-4 Recommendations for ESG Performance Evaluation in the Logistics Sector
detail.abstract: The logistics sector faces significant challenges in evaluating Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance due to limited interpretability, lack of sector-specific metrics, and absence of actionable decision-support systems. Most existing models often rely on static disclosures and fail to support transparent, company-specific ESG analysis. We developed an explainable AI-based models that integrates machine learning and deep learning models with post-model interpretability and GPT-4 based narrative recommendation to support transparent ESG performance evaluation. ESG scores were predicted for 178 logistics companies using multiple models. Among these, 1D-CNN and Autoencoder–SVR achieved the highest accuracy across ESG pillars. Features importance was quantified using SHAP value to ensure transparency and alignment with sector-relevant indicators. To bridge the gap between model output and managerial action, we employed GPT-4 to generate company-specific recommendations. Structured prompts were created using ESG scores, SHAP-ranked features, and operational profiles. GPT-4 produced narratives that identified weak ESG pillars and proposed targeted strategies for improvement.

title: Built Environment Digital Twin as Mediator of Shared Space: Balancing Personal Preferences and Group Decision Making
affiliations: National University of Singapore (NUS), National University of Singapore (NUS), National University of Singapore (NUS) and National University of Singapore (NUS)

detail.title: Built Environment Digital Twin as Mediator of Shared Space: Balancing Personal Preferences and Group Decision Making
detail.abstract: While digital twin (DT) technologies have enhanced occupant-centered personalization of indoor environmental quality, shared office environments still face challenges in balancing individual comfort preferences with group dynamics. Current DT systems often overlook the complexities of collective decision-making influenced by diverse needs and social hierarchies. This study examines how a DT system can mediate environmental control in shared workspaces by facilitating group decision-making through recommendations based on environmental factors and collected user data and real-time visualizations and improving the transparency and explainability of the decision process. To explore group decision-making processes, we developed a DT system that visualizes occupant preferences, provides AI-driven environmental recommendations, and supports real-time user input. The tests involved 120 participants in controlled co-working simulations. Results show that DT systems can serve as versatile mediators by promoting consensus with explainable, data-driven suggestions; supporting group decision-making using both historical and real-time data along with AI recommendations; empowering users to share their needs via feedback loops; integrating various preferences into a shared sense of satisfaction; and allowing quieter individuals to voice their needs. Participants looked for the DT systems to serve as a reliable teammate, simplifying decision-making and making comfort adjustments more inclusive and efficient. This research highlights the potential of DTs to enable fair and transparent control of environments in co-working spaces, offering a new approach for designing DT systems that address social dynamics, foster equity, and improve individual satisfaction while achieving group consensus in shared settings.

title: Bidding Demand Flexibility with Confidence: Novel Chance Constraints in an Aggregator Model of Optimally Controlled Thermal Storage Systems
affiliations: Pennsylvania State University and Pennsylvania State University

detail.title: Bidding Demand Flexibility with Confidence: Novel Chance Constraints in an Aggregator Model of Optimally Controlled Thermal Storage Systems
detail.abstract: To design and regulate a potential flexibility market that is open to bids from all types of distributed energy resources, including grid-interactive buildings, understanding the performance, availability and reliability of these resources is key. While scenario-based stochastic optimization accounts for uncertainty in the energy bidding process, a higher level of certainty that a select flexibility bid can be delivered in real time is required for demand flexibility to be adopted and integrated into the operational planning of novel electricity markets as a trustworthy and reliable grid resource.To simulate realistic bidding behaviors from grid-interactive buildings, and to enhance the reliability of bid delivery, this work designed a stochastic building aggregator model participating in an energy and flexibility market. The aggregator, which optimally controls a portfolio of building energy storage assets, is capable of generating a quantity bid for the day-ahead markets that maximizes its profit. To ensure the flexibility bid can be delivered in the real-time market, a novel chance constraint using empirical cumulative distribution function was formulated into a nested structure to allow users to stipulate any delivery confidence in the problem formulation. A case study tested on a portfolio of three office buildings participating in the PJM market demonstrated that the model exceeded the target bidding confidence of 80% among the testing scenarios, and achieved almost as much revenue as the perfect information case. Analysis on the detailed TES operation also revealed correlation between available flexibility and weather, suggesting possibilities to estimate building flexibility more efficiently in stochastic optimization problems.

title: Algorithmic Ambiguity: How Managers Navigate the Gray Zones of Ai Decision-Making
affiliations: University of Petroleum and Energy Studies (UPES)

detail.title: Algorithmic Ambiguity: How Managers Navigate the Gray Zones of Ai Decision-Making
detail.abstract: As AI becomes more common in business decision-making, managers are finding themselves in algorithmic gray areas more and more often. These are times when machine suggestions and human judgment don't agree. This paper looks at how managers interpret, question, or resist AI-generated decisions through narrative illustration, interviews with 26 middle managers, and conceptual framing. We talk about the Zone of Algorithmic Ambiguity and name four types of managers: the Deferrer, the Translator, the Challenger, and the Avoider. These examples show that AI decision-making isn't just technical; it's also very cultural and psychological. The paper gives organizations useful tips on how to support ethical and effective collaboration between people and AI. These include teaching people about AI, setting ethical boundaries, and allowing for smart disobedience. By doing this, we bring attention to a new leadership skill: the ability to deal with the gray.

title: Beyond the Pink Slip:Making Layoffs More Humane and Less Harmful in the Era of Ai
affiliations: University of Alabama at Birmingham, University of Alabama at Birmingham, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Cleveland State University

detail.title: Beyond the Pink Slip:Making Layoffs More Humane and Less Harmful in the Era of Ai
detail.abstract: This paper provides managers with best practices when implementing layoffs (employee downsizing). In this emerging era of artificial intelligence, some are predicting massive job losses, making downsizing events more likely. We discuss how to downsize employees with empathy and respect and provide recommendations on helping retained employees adjust. We also discuss the role of political skill (an interpersonal soft skill) that managers can utilize to be more effective during downsizing events.

title: Bridging the Global Cost Gap in Battery Cell Manufacturing – from Locational Factors to Factory Planning, and Policy Design
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Technische Universität München (TUM)

detail.title: Bridging the Global Cost Gap in Battery Cell Manufacturing – from Locational Factors to Factory Planning, and Policy Design
detail.abstract: The accelerating demand for lithium-ion battery cells necessitates a strategic, cost-competitive, and resilient battery production landscape. This study combines a battery market structure analysis with an extension of a techno-economic cost model to assess the impact of factory planning, location-specific factors, and policy instruments on lithium-ion battery production economics. While the political stability, the energy mix, and the financial incentives shape site attractiveness, a scenario analysis demonstrates that China’s cost advantage stems less from geographic location and more from lower material and equipment costs and superior production efficiency. Ramp-up delays are identified as a major cost risk, particularly in later stages, where weekly delays can add costs of $1M per GWh of annual output. Furthermore, different policy tools are compared, including direct per-kWh subsidies, investment-based payments, and import tariffs. Only sustained operating subsidies substantially reduce production cost gaps compared to China, while one-time incentives show limited impact. To balance cost-effectiveness and fiscal feasibility, a combined approach of different measures may be beneficial. The findings of this work underscore the importance of aligning industrial policy, factory planning, and research investment to secure sustainable competitive advantages in the evolving global battery market.

title: Price Promotions and Online Product Evaluations
affiliations: University College London - School of Management, London Business School and University College London - School of Management

detail.title: Price Promotions and Online Product Evaluations
detail.abstract: Digital products, such as mobile apps, e-books, and online courses, often have near-zero marginal costs of production and distribution. This enables frequent and steep price promotions. While it has been shown widely that price promotions increase sales, at least in the short term, the effect of price promotions on consumers' product evaluations is less clear. We study this question in the context of mobile apps, where price variations are common. Specifically, we examine how price promotions in Apple's App Store affect consumer evaluations measured by subsequent star ratings. Our results suggest that consumers tend to evaluate the product less favorably during price promotions than before the promotions. We provide evidence suggesting that reduced prices increase the likelihood of attracting consumers with lower valuations. Despite the reduced price, the app still represents a poor fit to these consumers' tastes. As a result of the mismatch between a consumer's taste and product characteristics, consumers who purchased during the promotion rate the app less favorably. These findings highlight a potential downside of aggressive price promotions for digital products, suggesting that firms must closely monitor online product evaluations to mitigate any negative impacts.

title: The Invisible Handcuffs of Tea: Why Premiumization is a Trap for Small Estates
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: The Invisible Handcuffs of Tea: Why Premiumization is a Trap for Small Estates

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author works at a family-run tea factory and developed this paper independently, outside of any formal institutional affiliation. Informal insights were also provided by her sister. There are no financial conflicts of interest or commercial endorsements associated with this work.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This study does not involve human subjects, medical data, or clinical research. Ethics approval was therefore not required.

detail.abstract: Small tea estates are often told to go premium by getting certifications, building a brand, and selling direct to consumers. But for most, the numbers simply do not work out. This paper looks at estates under 50 hectares and explores why premiumization often leads to higher costs without matching returns. Based on auction data, policy reviews, and field conversations, it shows that unbranded bulk channels offer more stable margins, while direct-to-consumer models bring high marketing and logistics costs. It also highlights practical alternatives like cooperative branding and niche B2B partnerships. The goal is not to dismiss premium efforts entirely, but to show that small estates need more grounded, scalable strategies that actually work.

detail.title: Agile Entrepreneurship in Action: Fostering Team Competencies through AI-Enhanced Digital Storytelling and Problem-Based Learning
detail.abstract: The study examines the applications of problem-based learning (PBL), Agile project management, and AI-enhanced digital storytelling in experiential learning to develop entrepreneurial and teamrelated proficiency among higher education learners. By getting a deeper look at an imaginary case study (the so-called Vision Team, an interdisciplinary team of students whose task is to create and market digital stories that align with Saudi vision 2030), the study presents how the collaborative platform (e.g., Trello, Miro), AI-based content generation tools (ChatGPT, Merlin, Leonardo), and iterative Agile sprints can assist with the development of the skills. Using a mixed-methods scenario that comprised project logs, peer and self-evaluations, and evaluator feedback, the study found significant gains in the sections of creativity, task ownership, leadership, and communication. The model's real-life successes, such as content monetization and user adoption, also demonstrate its value. Its results reemphasize the viability of integrating PBL, Agile techniques, and newer technologies in teaching entrepreneurship, as well as providing an instructional lesson for other business and media curriculum developers.

detail.title: Structural Equation Modeling of Technology Adoption, Competencies, and Culture as Predictors of Personnel Performance in Philippine HEIs

publicationDetails.detailsText: Psychology and Education: A Multidisciplinary

detail.abstract: In the digital era, non-teaching personnel in higher education institutions (HEIs) play a crucial role in institutional effectiveness and advancing sustainable development goals (SDGs), yet their performance remains underexplored. This study investigates the interplay of digital technology adoption, digital competencies, and organizational culture in shaping the performance of non-teaching personnel in Philippine higher education institutions (HEIs). Utilizing a quantitative research approach, data were collected from 319 non-teaching personnel across public HEIs in Bukidnon, Misamis Oriental, and Lanao del Norte through stratified and purposive sampling. This study utilized Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to analyze the relationships among variables and identify the best-fit model that explains personnel performance. The SEM analysis revealed that organizational culture (p<0.05, beta=0.312) and digital competencies (p<0.05, beta=0.533) have a significant influence on non-teaching personnel performance. On the other hand, organizational culture exerts the strongest influence on innovation (beta=0.922), digital competencies exerts the strongest influence on communication and collaboration (beta=0.843), and non-teaching personnel performance exerts the strongest influence on professional development engagement (beta=0.865). Although adopting digital technology was not directly significant, it indirectly influences personnel's performance by facilitating compatibility and ease of use through user-friendly digital tools. Also, data revealed that structural model-3 is the best fit model of public higher education institutions non-teaching personnel performance since the obtained value of the seven model fit indices used in this study are within the standard/good fit value range. The study reaffirms the resource-based view theory, emphasizing the strategic role of internal resources such as digital competencies and organizational culture. Based on the findings, SIGOD Personnel Performance Framework was developed, which emphasizes skills in the digital era, innovation in organizational culture, growth in professional development, optimization of performance metrics, and data-driven decision-making. Thus, the findings provide a valuable foundation for higher education institutions to implement strategic frameworks for workforce efficiency, adaptability, and sustainability.

detail.abstract:
This is a Comment on the ongoing debate surrounding the constitutionality of median bans recently enacted across the United States. This Comment focuses on Albuquerque, New Mexico’s recently enacted pedestrian-safety ordinance. The city enacted this ordinance after a 2021 Tenth Circuit ruling struck down a prior version of the ordinance for violating the First Amendment. The current median ordinance, like its predecessor, makes it illegal to sit or stand on certain street medians. This Comment examines whether Albuquerque’s current median ban constitutes a content-neutral, narrowly tailored “time, place, and manner” restriction under the First Amendment. Despite claims that the ban addresses a crisis of pedestrian fatalities, evidence shows the city’s ban does not serve a nonspeculative government interest by improving pedestrian safety. The ban also likely disproportionately restricts the rights of vulnerable populations. There is likely a lack of case-specific data showing that the ban positively impacts safety to a measurable degree that would justify such drastic infringement of the freedom of expression. In other words, the city’s law does not do what it purports to do while also imposing a broad speech restriction violative of the First Amendment.

            This is also a Comment on the intersection of constitutional rights, road safety, and governance strategies. Instead of taking the path of criminalizing poverty, panhandling, and homelessness, legislatures at all levels of government should instead seek to address the root causes through measures like infrastructure improvements and affordable housing. But this Comment recognizes these solutions come with immense expense and thus recommends three stopgap measures that municipalities could feasibly implement: mobile outreach services, donation deflection programs, and day-labor initiatives. Legislatures in Albuquerque and in localities across America should take caution to avoid restricting the First Amendment rights of panhandlers, pedestrians, motorists, and, ultimately, everyone, through median bans that have little impact on public safety.
